item.title: The vegetable seller who sparked the protests
item.description: Jobless graduate Mohamed Bouazizi starts selling vegetables. When police seize his cart, he sets fire to himself and later dies. The act, following WikiLeaks' publication of US criticisms of the regime, provokes young Tunisians to protest

item.title: Tunisian president vows to punish protesters
item.description: After 10 days of protests, Zine el Abidine Ben Ali appears on television, promising action on job creation, but also that 'the law will be applied in all firmness' to protesters

item.title: 21 die in bombing of Coptic church
item.description: 21 die in a suspected al-Qaida suicide bombing outside a Coptic church in Alexandria. Mubarak pledges: 'We will cut off the hands of those plotting against Egypt's security'. Christians take to the streets, clashing with police and Muslims

item.title: Riots in Algeria over unemployment and food prices
item.description: Police respond with teargas to demonstrators throwing stones and setting up barricades in Algiers during protests over food prices and unemployment

item.title: Protests continue, leading to several deaths in violent clashes
item.description: Protesters clash with police and set fire to cars in several Tunisian cities. Security services respond violently

item.title: Protests continue, leading to several deaths in violent clashes
item.description: Protesters clash with police and set fire to cars in several Tunisian cities. Security services respond violently

item.title: Protests continue, leading to several deaths in violent clashes
item.description: Protesters clash with police and set fire to cars in several Tunisian cities. Security services respond violently

item.title: Suicide protest in Algeria
item.description: Mohsen Bouterfif burns himself to death after failing to find a job and a house, in an apparent copycat suicide that echoes the young Tunisian Mohamed Bouazizi, whose death sparked off the trouble in mid-December

item.title: Ben Ali flees
item.description: Tunisian president finally bows to protests and flees to Saudi Arabia by way of Malta

item.title: Gaddafi condemns Tunisian uprising
item.description: The Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi makes a televised address, 'pained' at events across the border, amid reports of unrest on the streets of Libya

item.title: Man sets fire to himself outside Egypt's parliament
item.description: A man sets fire to himself near the Egyptian parliament building in Cairo, apparently in protest at economic conditions. He is taken to hospital

item.title: ElBaradei warns of 'Tunisia-style explosion' in Egpyt
item.description: The Egyptian dissident Mohamed ElBaradei warns of a 'Tunisia-style explosion' in his country as self-immolation protests proliferate and anti-government activists announce plans for a nationwide 'day of anger'

item.title: Switzerland freezes Ben Ali's assets
item.description: Switzerland's federal council agrees to freeze any assets of Tunisia's ousted president

item.title: Yemeni activists arrested
item.description: Yemen is hit by fresh protests after the arrest of 19 opposition activists including Tawakul Karman, a prominent female activist who had called for the ousting of President Ali Abdullah Saleh

item.title: France offers aid to Tunisia's interim government
item.description: Nicolas Sarkozy admits he underestimated the protest movement that ousted President Ben Ali. As Tunisian police fire teargas to disperse protesters outside government offices in Tunis, Sarkozy promises emergency financial aid to the interim government

item.title: Mass protests against Mubarak regime
item.description: The first coordinated protests turn Cairo into a 'war-zone' as protests calling for the resignation of Hosni Mubarak erupt nationwide - Egypt's largest demonstration in a generation. The government blocks Twitter and shuts down mobile and internet networks

item.title: Day of rage against Hezbollah
item.description: Thousands of Sunnis take part in a 'day of rage' in opposition to the prospect of a new government under Hezbollah control after the ousting of Saad Hariri as prime minister of the US-allied government

item.title: Egypt crackdown
item.description: Security forces use tear gas and beatings; hundreds are arrested including foreign journalists. European leaders condemn the tactics, and the Anonymous hackers' group threatens cyber-attacks if the Egyptian government does not stop censoring the media

item.title: Demonstrations in Sana'a
item.description: Thousands of people take to the streets of Sana'a, calling for an end to the reign of President Ali Abdullah Saleh in some of the biggest anti-government rallies Yemen has seen for a decade

item.title: ElBaradei returns to Egypt
item.description: Egyptian opposition leader Mohamed ElBaradei returns to Egypt to join anti-government protests and tells the Guardian Hosni Mubarak's regime is 'on its last legs'

item.title: Protests in Palestine
item.description: Thousands of people demonstrate in Gaza after leaked documents reveal the extent of concessions Palestinian negotiators were prepared to offer Israel during a decade of peace talks

item.title: Unrest spreads to Jordan
item.description: Thousands of people gather in the capital Amman to demand political change

item.title: Mubarak tries to head off protests
item.description: President Mubarak makes his first TV appearance after four days of protest and violent crackdown, sacking his government and pledging his commitment to democracy, but refusing to step down. At least 25 die as demonstrations continue

item.title: Mubarak appoints a vice-president
item.description: Hosni Mubarak appoints his intelligence chief and confidant, Omar Suleiman, as his first-ever vice-president in the first sign of a possible succession plan. The death toll reaches 100. Protesters chant 'Mubarak, your plane is ready'

item.title: ElBaradei tells Mubarak to go
item.description: Mohamed ElBaradei urges Mubarak to step down and calls for talks on a new government with the army, which he calls 'part of the Egyptian people'. Al-Jazeera TV is ordered to close over its reporting of the protests

item.title: Army tells demonstrators: we will not fire
item.description: Egypt's army makes its first explicit statement in favour of the protesters, telling them: 'The armed forces will not resort to use of force against our great people'. The new vice-president offers talks with the demonstrators

item.title: Mubarak says he will go - but not yet
item.description: President Mubarak pledges to step down at the next election and pave the way for a new leader. He will stay in power now to oversee the transition, he says - a position immediately rejected by demonstrators

item.title: Brutal crackdown in Tahrir Square
item.description: Club-wielding supporters of Hosni Mubarak, some on horses and camels, move to crush the uprising as they storm Tahrir Square. Tony Blair praises Mubarak and warns against rushed elections that could bring the Muslim Brotherhood to power

item.title: Yemeni president to step down - in 2013
item.description: In a last-ditch attempt to stop protests demanding his resignation, President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen says he will end his 32-year rule in 2013 and that his son, Ahmed, will not succeed him

item.title: Yemeni 'day of rage'
item.description: Tens of thousands of Yemenis demonstrate in an opposition-led 'day of rage'. Supporters of President Ali Abdullah Saleh organise counter-demonstrations

item.title: Rioting is bad for business
item.description: Egypt's vice-president, Omar Suleiman, warns protesters that rioting is chasing away foreign tourists and investors. He says Egypt has lost at least $1bn in tourism in nine days and that a million tourists have left

item.title: The day of departure
item.description: In Egypt's biggest demonstration yet, hundreds of thousands of people stage a 'day of departure' protest in Cairo's Tahrir Square. Mubarak stays put

item.title: Salaries and pensions rise
item.description: Egypt's new cabinet announces a 15% rise in salaries and pensions to try to draw the sting from public protests calling for Hosni Mubarak's resignation. Demonstrators are unmoved

item.title: Freed Google man hailed
item.description: Wael Ghonim, the Google executive who helped organise the protests that started Egypt's uprising, is hailed as a hero after being released from detention. There are calls for him to be appointed spokesman for the democracy movement

item.title: Obama ends Egypt dithering
item.description: Mubarak confounds a day of fevered speculation that he is to announce his resignation. President Obama finally ends two weeks of dithering and demands that Egypt present an unequivocal path to democracy

item.title: Mubarak resigns - and Egypt celebrates
item.description: After 18 days of mass protest, Egypt's vice-president, Omar Suleiman, finally announces that President Hosni Mubarak is standing down and handing power to the military. Euphoric crowds pour into Tahrir Square to celebrate

item.title: Algeria cracks down on protesters
item.description: Algerian police beat back around 2,000 demonstrators who try to rally in central Algiers as aftershocks from the Egyptian revolution rumble throughout the Middle East

item.title: Egyptian army insists it will stay put
item.description: The military rejects protesters' demands for a swift transfer of power to a civilian administration, suspending the constitution and saying it will rule by martial law until elections. Earlier troops were sent to clear demonstrators from Tahrir Square

item.title: Arrests and deaths as protests spread to more countries
item.description: Egypt's uprising sends shockwaves across the Middle East, with two deaths in clashes in Iran and Bahrain and violent demonstrations in Yemen, as well as further protests across Egypt. Iran's protests are its biggest since the 2009 election

item.title: Arrests and deaths as protests spread to more countries
item.description: Egypt's uprising sends shockwaves across the Middle East, with two deaths in clashes in Iran and Bahrain and violent demonstrations in Yemen, as well as further protests across Egypt. Iran's protests are its biggest since the 2009 election

item.title: Arrests and deaths as protests spread to more countries
item.description: Egypt's uprising sends shockwaves across the Middle East, with two deaths in clashes in Iran and Bahrain and violent demonstrations in Yemen, as well as further protests across Egypt. Iran's protests are its biggest since the 2009 election

item.title: The hunt for Mubarak's millions
item.description: Britain's Serious Organised Crime Agency begins tracing the bank accounts of Hosni Mubarak's cabinet after the Egyptian government made a formal request for a freeze on the assets of the ousted president and his former colleagues

item.title: Protesters at Pearl Roundabout
item.description: Bahrain's main opposition party withdraws from parliament in protest after troops fire on mourners at the funeral for a pro-democracy protester shot dead a day earlier. Thousands of protesters set up tents on Pearl Roundabout in Manama

item.title: MPs call for death of opposition leaders
item.description: Hardline MPs demand that two senior opposition leaders be executed after rare anti-government demonstrations left one person dead and dozens injured

item.title: US journalist attacked
item.description: CBS News journalist Lara Logan is recovering in hospital this week after being violently attacked and sexually assaulted by a mob in Egypt's Tahrir Square on Friday, according to a statement by CBS.

item.title: Protests in Benghazi
item.description: Protests erupt in Libya's second city after the arrest of a human rights campaigner. Witnesses say a peaceful protest was attacked by Gaddafi loyalists. Unrest spreads to Zentan, south of Tripoli, where a police station is burnt

item.title: Protesters killed in Manama
item.description: At least four people are killed in an early-morning raid by security forces on Pearl Square, the focal point of anti-government demonstrations in Bahrain, sparking street battles with riot police

item.title: Libya's day of rage
item.description: Libya's government brings out its supporters to express their loyalty to try to stifle a planned 'day of rage', but sporadic violence continue in the east with at least 15 people reported killed

item.title: Libya's day of rage
item.description: Libya's government brings out its supporters to express their loyalty to try to stifle a planned 'day of rage', but sporadic violence continue in the east with at least 15 people reported killed

item.title: News blackout hides Libya chaos
item.description: Dozens of protesters are reported killed during attacks by security forces in eastern cities including Benghazi, with conflicting reports from the region impossible to verify because of the media blackout imposed by the Gaddafi regime

item.title: Troops fire on protesters
item.description: At least one person is killed and dozens injured when soldiers open fire as hundreds of protesters march towards Pearl roundabout, the scene of violent clashes a day earlier

item.title: Protests spread to Tripoli
item.description: Gaddafi's son goes on Libyan TV to defend his father's 41-year rule as protests reach Tripoli. The worst violence yet in the Arab uprisings sees troops and mercenaries shooting unarmed demonstrators in Benghazi. The death toll passes 230

item.title: Riots leave five dead
item.description: Thousands protest peacefully in Rabat, Casablanca, Tangier and Marrakech demanding a new government and an end to corruption. Later five people die in a fire at a bank in Al Hoceima. Protesters blame rioting on football hooligans

item.title: Pilots defect after orders to kill
item.description: Two Libyan air force pilots flee to Malta after being ordered to bomb civilians. Libyan diplomats in several countries and international organisations resign in protest at the regime's violent crackdown. Oil prices hit a two-year high

item.title: Gaddafi: I'll die a martyr
item.description: Muammar Gaddafi delivers a ranting TV address urging loyalists to take to the streets to fight 'greasy rats' in the pay of enemies ranging from the US to al-Qaida. He insists he will die in Libya rather than flee

item.title: First protesters killed in Sana'a
item.description: Unrest in Yemen intensifies when at least two protesters are shot dead during a street battle between pro- and anti-government demonstrators near Sana'a University the first deaths in the city after 12 days of protests

item.title: Inside 'Free Libya'
item.description: Martin Chulov, the first foreign journalist to reach Benghazi after a regime ban on the international media, reports on a city that has fallen to rebels as anti-Gaddafi rebels take control

item.title: Libya rebels isolate Gaddafi
item.description: Opposition activists increase the pressure on Muammar Gaddafi's ailing regime, shutting down oil exports and mobilising rebel groups in the west of the country as the revolution rapidly spreads

item.title: Gaddafi pledges to 'open up the arsenals'
item.description: Libya's uprising reaches the heart of Tripoli as anti-regime demonstrators defy a security clampdown to demand Gaddafi's overthrow. Gunmen in cars reportedly open fire on protesters. Gaddafi gives another defiant speech, pledging to 'open up the arsenals'

item.title: Middle East's 'day of rage'
item.description: Protests erupt in cities across the Middle East. At least six people are killed in Iraq; thousands take to the streets in Sana'a; and Egyptians gather in Cairo's Tahrir Square to demand an accelerated reform programme

item.title: Middle East's 'day of rage'
item.description: Protests erupt in cities across the Middle East. At least six people are killed in Iraq; thousands take to the streets in Sana'a; and Egyptians gather in Cairo's Tahrir Square to demand an accelerated reform programme

item.title: Middle East's 'day of rage'
item.description: Protests erupt in cities across the Middle East. At least six people are killed in Iraq; thousands take to the streets in Sana'a; and Egyptians gather in Cairo's Tahrir Square to demand an accelerated reform programme

item.title: Remote strongholds rise up against Gaddafi
item.description: In the town of Ajdabiya, 160km south of Benghazi, every official building has been torched and ransacked, just like the state institutions to the east

item.title: PM resigns amid arrest
item.description: Tunisia faces renewed turmoil as Mohamed Ghannouchi resigns as prime minister of the post-revolution government amid further clashes between police and protesters. The interim president, Fouad Mebazaa, names former government minister Beji Caid-Essebsi to the post

item.title: Rebels capture Zawiyah
item.description: Residents celebrate as anti-Gaddafi revolutionaries take control of Zawiyah, just 30 miles from Libya's capital

item.title: UK helps with refugee airlift
item.description: A mass airlift of Egyptian refugees from the Libyan-Tunisian border to Cairo involving British, French and Tunisian planes begins, as Arab states caution against intervention in the Libyan conflict

item.title: Obama urges Gaddafi to stand down
item.description: Obama urges Gaddafi to stand down, saying he has 'lost the legitimacy to lead' Libya after Tripoli's violent response to the protests. He doesn't. The international criminal court says it will investigate Gaddafi for possible crimes against humanity

item.title: Iraq protesters defy security crackdown
item.description: Hundreds of people converge on Baghdad's Liberation Square for an anti-government demonstration as Iraqis rally for the second Friday in a row, despite a vehicle ban that forces many to walk for hours to the centre

item.title: New PM rouses Cairo crowds
item.description: Egypt's new prime minister, Essam Sharaf, appointed by the military, calls on thousands of cheering protesters in Tahrir Square to rebuild the country and says he will step down if he fails to meet their demands

item.title: Gaddafi's forces counter-attack
item.description: A concerted fightback by Gaddafi's troops sees opposition forces encircled in Zawiyah after some of the most savage fighting in Libya's two-week uprising. The two sides dispute who controls what

item.title: Public protests banned
item.description: Public protests are banned in Saudi Arabia after demonstrations by minority Shia groups. The ruling comes after two weeks of Shia agitation, during which 22 people were arrested

item.title: SAS mission humiliated
item.description: A British diplomatic effort to reach out to Libyan rebels ends in humiliation as a team of British special forces and intelligence agents are briefly detained by farmworkers and then ignominiously leave Libya

item.title: Protests banned
item.description: Public protests are banned after demonstrations by minority Shia groups. Senior clerics say: 'Demonstrations are forbidden in this country. The correct way in sharia of realising common interest is by advising, which is what the prophet Muhammad established'

item.title: Gaddafi's jets slow rebel advance
item.description: Libyan jets launch multiple strikes on opposition fighters near the oil city of Ras Lanuf to try to halt the rebel advance. The UN secretary general calls for an end to attacks on civilians and warns of 'carnage'

item.title: Prisoners riot in Sana'a
item.description: 2,000 inmates stage a revolt at a prison in the capital, take a dozen guards hostage and join calls by anti-government protesters for Saleh to step down

item.title: Million-woman march
item.description: A march in Cairo to coincide with the 100th international women's day turns ugly with insults and scuffles at a counter-demonstration

item.title: UN mulls no-fly zone
item.description: Gaddafi's forces launch a 'final assault' on Zawiyah. David Cameron and Barack Obama agree to draw up 'the full spectrum' of military responses to the Libyan crisis, including a possible no-fly zone

item.title: Ousted president's party dissolved
item.description: A Tunisian court rules that the party of the former president, Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali, be dissolved, triggering street celebrations as one of the last vestiges of the ousted leader's era is dismantled

item.title: Soldiers fire on student protest
item.description: The Yemeni government escalates efforts to stop mass protests calling for the president's removal, with soldiers firing rubber bullets and tear gas at students camped at a university in Sana'a, wounding at least 98, officials say

item.title: Gaddafi resistance threat on no-fly zone
item.description: Colonel Muammar Gaddafi warns that the imposition of a no-fly zone in Libyan airspace will be met with armed resistance and taken as proof that western powers are trying to steal his country's oil

item.title: President offers new constitution
item.description: Yemen's president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, pledges to create a parliamentary system of government in a bid to defuse increasingly violent protest against his 32-year rule. An opposition spokesman rejects the proposal and calls for rallies to continue

item.title: Gaddafi takes key towns
item.description: The Gaddafi regime warns that the 'time for action' has arrived as a sustained military assault forces the defeat of Libyan rebels in the strategically important town of Zawiya and their retreat from Ras Lanuf

item.title: Sarkozy threat of air strikes
item.description: Nicolas Sarkozy calls for targeted air strikes against the Libyan regime if Gaddafi's forces use chemical weapons or air strikes against civilians. The EU foreign policy chief warns that a no-fly zone could risk civilian lives

item.title: Saudi day of rage quelled
item.description: Expectations that the unrest sweeping the Arab world would spread to its most conservative kingdom are dashed as Saudi security forces come out in strength in Riyadh, ensuring pro-democracy campaigners managed only small demonstrations in eastern provinces

item.title: Rebel forces routed
item.description: Muammar Gaddafi's forces rout rebels in eastern Libya, driving them into retreat from the town of Brega under a rain of rockets and shells, and opening up the road to the principal opposition stronghold, Benghazi

item.title: Yemen police kill protesters
item.description: Yemeni security forces kill four people and wound hundreds more in the second day of a harsh crackdown on anti-government protests, witnesses say. One of the dead was a 15-year-old student

item.title: Child soldiers suppressing protests'
item.description: Iran's Islamic regime is using 'child soldiers' to suppress anti-government demonstrations, a tactic that could breach international law forbidding the use of underage combatants, human rights activists say

item.title: Al-Jazeera cameraman killed
item.description: An al-Jazeera cameraman, Ali Hassan al-Jaber, died near the rebel-held city of Benghazi in eastern Libya after he was hunted down and ambushed by forces loyal to Muammar Gaddafi, according to sources at the broadcaster

item.title: Kill Gaddafi, rebel leaders urge
item.description: Libya's revolutionary leadership urges western powers to assassinate Muammar Gaddafi and launch military strikes against his forces to protect rebel-held cities from the threat of bloody assault

item.title: Saudi troops enter Bahrain
item.description: Saudi Arabia moves to bolster Bahrain's embattled royal family, sending military forces across the causeway linking the two kingdoms after violent weekend pro-democracy protests by Shia demonstrators all but overwhelmed police

item.title: Martial law declared
item.description: The streets of Bahrain's capital, Manama, erupt in violence again as the besieged monarch declares martial law and orders troops to take all measures to quell a festering rebellion

item.title: Government boosts wages
item.description: In a bid to stave off further unrest the government uses oil revenue to boost the pay of police, teachers and magistrates and shelves plans to crack down on the informal economy

item.title: Protests demand end to divisions
item.description: Tens of thousands of people take part in protests in Gaza and the West Bank, demanding an end to political division and the Israeli occupation

item.title: Opposition members held
item.description: Security forces in Bahrain arrest six key opposition members whom they accuse of having contacted 'foreign agents', as a crackdown on a two-month anti-government rebellion continues. Britons are urged to leave Bahrain

item.title: UN backs no-fly zone
item.description: The security council votes for a resolution authorising all necessary measures to protect civilians under threat of attack, in particular Benghazi. Ten members vote in favour, with five abstaining. The resolution rules out putting troops on the ground

item.title: King announces jobs and housing package
item.description: King Abdullah promises a multibillion-pound package of reforms, pay rises, cash and apartments in the Arab world's most expensive attempt to appease protesters. He also creates 60,000 security forces jobs - easing unemployment while bolstering any crackdown

item.title: Pearl Roundabout destroyed
item.description: The hub of Bahrain's rebellion is destroyed under government orders as the country's embattled leaders intensify moves to crush the reformist movement

item.title: Dozens of protesters killed
item.description: At least 45 people are killed and hundreds wounded as security forces and plainclothes government loyalists fire on protesters in Sana'a. It is the worst day of violence in a month of protests against President Saleh

item.title: Security forces kill Syrian protesters
item.description: Syrian police seal off the southern city of Daraa after security forces kill at least five protesters in the gravest unrest in Syria for years

item.title: Operation Odyssey Dawn
item.description: Western air and missile strikes against Muammar Gaddafi's military in Operation Odyssey Dawn, the biggest assault on an Arab regime since the invasion of Iraq in 2003, halt the offensive against rebels in Benghazi, the US says

item.title: President fires cabinet
item.description: Yemen's president sacks his cabinet amid escalating protests demanding his resignation. Tens of thousands of mourners had gathered in Sana'a at the funeral for 52 protesters killed two days earlier in a sniper attack by government loyalists

item.title: Thousands march against corruption
item.description: Thousands of people march in cities across Morocco after King Mohamed fails to act on constitutional reform pledges made after last month's protests

item.title: Egyptians vote for change
item.description: More than 77% of voters in Egypt support changes that will provide a blueprint for parliamentary and presidential elections to be held within the next six months. Voting is largely problem-free

item.title: Coalition strikes hit Gaddafi compound
item.description: A building in Colonel Gaddafi's compound in Tripoli is destroyed in the second night of air strikes against the regime. US and UK military officials deny that the Libyan leader himself was targeted

item.title: Military commanders defect
item.description: Eleven military commanders, including a senior general, defect from the regime, promising to protect anti-government protesters in Sana'a. Ambassadors, governors, editors, businessmen and ruling party cadres announce their allegiance to protesters as rival tanks roll onto the streets

item.title: Is Gaddafi a target?
item.description: A third night of air attacks hits Libya. David Cameron says Gaddafi may be a legitimate target the chief of the defence staff denies this. A Nato dispute delays handover of operational command from the US

item.title: Nato takes charge of Libya assault
item.description: Britain, France and the US agree that Nato will take military command of Libya's no-fly zone; a separate body including Arab countries will have political oversight. A defiant Gaddafi criticises the air strikes 'by a bunch of fascists'

item.title: Six die in Syria mosque attack
item.description: Syrian forces kill at least six people in an attack on a mosque in the southern city of Deraa, the site of protests challenging President Assad's regime. Residents say up to 100 people die in a 24-hour assault

item.title: MPs pass emergency laws
item.description: Emergency legislation requested by President Saleh in a bid to quash an anti-government uprising suspends the constitution, allows media censorship, bans street protests and gives security forces 30 days of far-reaching powers to arrest and detain suspects

item.title: Shorts fired as Syrians defy crackdown
item.description: Thousands of Syrians defy a government crackdown to take to the streets in Deraa in funeral marches for protesters killed by police gunfire the previous day, it is reported. The government says it will consider reforms

item.title: French jets down a Libyan plane
item.description: French fighter jets destroy a Libyan plane in Misrata: the first enforcement of the no-fly zone. Tripoli claims nearly 100 civilians died in allied strikes. Mourners call for revenge at the funeral of 18 civilians reported killed yesterday

item.title: Rebels arrest Yvonne Fletcher murder suspect
item.description: The man suspected of murdering PC Yvonne Fletcher outside the Libyan embassy in London in 1984 is arrested by rebel forces in the country and is in custody in the rebel stronghold of Benghazi

item.title: Thousands rally in Sana'a
item.description: Tens of thousands gather to demand President Saleh's resignation. The president tells a rival crowd of his own supporters that he is prepared to surrender power but only to 'safe hands'

item.title: Protests spread to Damascus
item.description: Hundreds march in Homs, Hama, Tel and Latakia and in towns surrounding Deraa, with smaller protests in Aleppo and Damascus. Unconfirmed reports say at least 23 people were killed, some of them in Damascus, hitherto unaffected

item.title: Government loyalists attack pro-reform vigil
item.description: One person is killed and 100 wounded when government loyalists attack a weekly pro-reform vigil in Amman. The violence is the first in two months of protests which have seen the king sack his cabinet and pledge reforms

item.title: Air strikes drive Gaddafi loyalists out
item.description: The strategic town of Ajdabiya falls to rebels - their first significant victory since allied air strikes began. Iman al-Obeidi is arrested after interrupting a press conference to tell foreign journalists she was repeatedly raped by government militiamen

item.title: New clashes in Latakia, Tafa and Deraa
item.description: The UN urges Syria's government to show restraint after new clashes in Latakia, where two people are reportedly shot dead, and in the southern towns of Tafa and Deraa. Burials take place for 55 people killed so far

item.title: 12 dead in Syria protests
item.description: The army is deployed in force in Latakia after two days of fierce anti-government protests in which at least 12 died. The government blames the deaths on 'attacks by armed elements'; activists say security forces opened fire

item.title: Turkey offers to broker ceasefire
item.description: Turkey offers to broker a ceasefire, warning against a long conflict. Rebels assisted by coalition air strikes recapture oil towns, including Brega, Ras Lanuf and Bin Jawad. Iman al-Obeidi's family deny regime claims that she has been freed

item.title: Rebels advance on Sirte
item.description: Libyan rebels advance on Muammar Gaddafi's home city, Sirte, rapidly moving more than 150 miles west along Libya's coastal road, recapturing several towns without resistance. Sirte marks the boundary between the east and west of Libya

item.title: Forces fire on Syria protesters
item.description: Security forces fire shots and teargas to disperse up to 4,000 protesters in Deraa as frustration mounts at the slow pace of promised reforms. Human rights activists say more than 150 people have been killed in 11 days

item.title: Many die in factory blasts
item.description: At least 121 people die after a series of explosions at a munitions factory in southern Yemen as President Ali Abdullah Saleh loses his grip on parts of the country amid an anti-regime revolt

item.title: Clinton talks tough on Libya
item.description: Coalition military action in Libya will continue until Muammar Gaddafi complies with UN security council resolution 1973, Hillary Clinton tells world leaders meeting in London. Gaddafi's forces attack rebel fighters east of Sirte, forcing a retreat

item.title: Syria's cabinet resigns
item.description: Syria's President Assad sacks his cabinet and hints at reforms amid the worst unrest in decades. Earlier, hundreds of thousands of regime supporters gathered in Damascus and other cities as the government tries to show it retains support

item.title: Libyan foreign minister defects
item.description: Gaddafi's foreign minister Moussa Koussa quits and flees to the UK in a flight arranged by British intelligence. Obama signs a secret order authorising covert help for the rebels. Gaddafi's forces retake Ras Lanuf and Brega

item.title: Assad speech angers protesters
item.description: President Assad blames foreign conspirators for recent unrest and fails to deliver decisive reforms in his first public appearance since protests started. Demonstrators had hoped he would lift an emergency law banning public dissent

item.title: Al-Qaida 'welcomes uprisings'
item.description: Senior al-Qaida leaders welcome the Arab uprisings in their first comprehensive statement, published online. Fugitive preacher Anwar al-Awlaki says unrest in Tunisia, Egypt, Libya gives the region 'a chance to breathe again after three decades of suffocation'

item.title: Security forces kill three protesters
item.description: Thousands angered by President Assad's speech take to the streets on a day dubbed the 'Friday of Martyrs'. Security forces open fire on demonstrators in Douma and Kafer Souseh, killing three people and injuring scores more

item.title: Gaddafi regime starts talks with west
item.description: A senior aide to Gaddafi's son Saif Al-Islam visits London for confidential talks with British officials and the country's former prime minister says Libyan officials are trying to negotiate with the west, as rebels outline ceasefire conditions

item.title: Protesters mourn shooting victims
item.description: Protesters return to Damascus as funerals are held for those killed in an alleged government massacre. Angry mourners chant 'down with the regime' as eight victims, believed to have been targeted by government snipers during protests, are buried

item.title: Gaddafi minister flies to Athens
item.description: Deputy foreign minister Abdul Ati al-Obeidi flies to Greece. Dimitris Droustas, Greece's foreign minister, says: 'From the Libyan envoy's comments it appears that the regime is seeking a solution'

item.title: UK increases number of Tornados
item.description: David Cameron announces an increase in the number of Tornado strike aircraft to be deployed to hit Gaddafi's forces as the US moves out of frontline operations

item.title: 400 hurt as police fire on protest
item.description: Yemeni security forces and gunmen in civilian clothes fire on protesters marching through the southern city of Taiz, killing at least 12 people amid reports that the US now wants President Ali Abdullah Saleh to quit

item.title: Fresh clashes in Taiz
item.description: Thousands of demonstrators are attacked by troops and plainclothes police in Taiz. Hundreds are wounded and dozens taken to hospital. Amid continuing unrest, Abubakr al-Qirbi, the acting foreign minister, says the government agrees to peace talks in Riyadh

item.title: Nato lacks strike aircraft
item.description: Nato lacks strike aircraft for its bombing campaign against Gaddafi only days after taking command. The pressure is on for other European countries to follow Cameron's lead and offer more jets after the Americans withdrew their attack aircraft

item.title: Syria reaches out to conservative Muslims
item.description: Syria closes the country's only casino and reverses a ban on teachers wearing the Islamic veil in an attempt to reach out to conservative Muslims ahead of planned pro-democracy demonstrations

item.title: Libyan rebels to be trained
item.description: Senior British defence sources reveal that Britain will urge Arab countries to train the disorganised Libyan rebels to strengthen their position on the battlefield before negotiations on a ceasefire

item.title: Jordanian self-immolates
item.description: A Jordanian man sets himself on fire outside the prime minister's office in Amman and is in critical condition with third-degree burns. Prosecutors charge 80 people with resisting police intervention during a demonstration on 25 March

item.title: Turkey proposes peace plan
item.description: Turkey proposes a path to peaceful resolution to the deadlocked conflict in Libya, involving a withdrawal by Gaddafi's forces from cities held by the rebels, a humanitarian corridor to allow aid to enter and democratic reform

item.title: Protesters return to Tahrir Square
item.description: More than 100,000 protesters gather in Cairo's Tahrir Square, piling pressure on the ruling military council to meet demands including the prosecution of Hosni Mubarak in one of the biggest demonstrations since he was ousted

item.title: President backs away from peace plan
item.description: President Saleh backs away from a plan being drawn up by Gulf states to broker an end to his 33-year rule. Speaking at a rally of his supporters, he accuses them of 'blatant interference in Yemeni affairs'

item.title: No Nato apology for attack on rebels
item.description: Nato 'strongly regrets' the loss of life caused by an attack on rebel forces in eastern Libya in which at least five people were killed, saying it had not been told the rebels had tanks

item.title: Death toll rises in biggest day of unrest
item.description: Anti-government demonstrations spread across Syria with the highest turnout yet and at least 22 people are killed in Deraa when troops open fire on thousands of protesters and ambulances are prevented from reaching the scene

item.title: Troops attack Tahrir Square protesters
item.description: At least two people are killed when soldiers armed with clubs and rifles storm Cairo's Tahrir Square in a pre-dawn raid on protesters calling for the trial of Mubarak and the removal of the army chief

item.title: Red Cross ship arrives in Misrata
item.description: A Red Cross ship carrying medical supplies docks in the besieged Libyan city of Misrata as aid workers also make their way to Zawiyah, a coastal town near Tripoli that has been virtually off limits to aid agencies

item.title: Syria death toll rises
item.description: At least three people are killed and scores more wounded in shootings in the port city of Banias amid reports that the army is being deployed. Human rights groups are concerned about the rising death toll

item.title: Gaddafi forces move towards Benghazi
item.description: Gaddafi's forces fight their way toward Benghazi, as five African leaders arrive in Tripoli in an attempt to broker a ceasefire. Rebel defences around Ajdabiya appear to be failing as Gaddafi's soldiers break into the strategic town

item.title: Mubarak breaks silence to deny corruption
item.description: Mubarak gives his first public address since his removal from power to deny that he stole billions of dollars from his country's coffers, as a new wave of protests turns against the military

item.title: Thousands march over protesters' deaths
item.description: Thousands of people march in the capital, Sana'a, in protest at the deaths of demonstrators on Friday in the southern city of Taiz. Amid daily protests, Gulf Arab foreign ministers meet in Saudi Arabia to discuss mediation plans

item.title: Saleh promises to step down in 2013
item.description: President Saleh hails an initiative brokered by Gulf states that would see him step down and transfer power to his deputy. He insists he will when his term ends in 2013 but protesters demand his immediate deposition

item.title: Human rights activist summoned for questioning
item.description: Bahrain's most prominent human rights activist is accused of tampering with photographs of a man who died in custody last week and is summoned for questioning amid a crackdown on critics since the imposition of military rule

item.title: Libyan revolutionary council rejects peace initiative
item.description: Libya's rebel leadership rejects an African Union peace initiative because it does not require Gaddafi to immediately relinquish power. The view is backed by thousands of demonstrators who carry signs saying: 'No solution with Gaddafi staying'

item.title: Syrian soldiers shot for not firing on protesters
item.description: Syrian soldiers are shot by security forces after refusing to fire on protesters, witnesses say, as a crackdown on anti-government demonstrations intensifies. Mourad Hejjo, a conscript from Madaya, is named as one of those shot by security snipers

item.title: Moussa Koussa to leave Britain
item.description: Moussa Koussa, Libya's former foreign minister, is allowed to leave the UK after being questioned over the Lockerbie bombing. Koussa says Libya risks becoming a 'new Somalia', while France says Nato is not doing enough to protect civilians

item.title: Mubarak detained over corruption allegations
item.description: Former president Mubarak is detained after reportedly suffering a heart attack and his two sons are held in prison as officials investigate allegations of corruption and abuse and the squandering of public funds

item.title: Gaddafi must go, contact group says
item.description: Gaddafi's regime has 'lost all legitimacy' and he must leave power, the 21-member 'contact group' of Arab and western ministers meeting in Qatar unanimously declare. Disagreements emerge over whether UN resolutions allow the delivery of weapons to rebels

item.title: Military violence escalates
item.description: A showdown looms in Yemen after six people are killed in a skirmish between rival military factions in Sana'a, as hundreds of thousands of anti-regime protesters rally across the country

item.title: Obama signals US return to Libya
item.description: President Obama signals America's return to the forefront of the international effort in Libya, writing a joint article with David Cameron and Nicolas Sarkozy in which they commit to pursue military action until Gaddafi has been removed

item.title: Rebels call for Nato troops in Misrata
item.description: Libyan rebels urge Nato to send in troops as Misrata comes under renewed pounding by Gaddafi's forces and evidence mounts of the use of cluster bombs against the besieged civilian population

item.title: Saudi link to Bahrain repression
item.description: Evidence emerges that plainclothes Saudi forces have been involved in violence against the Shia opposition. New arrests and the alleged death of a female student fuel sectarian tensions, prompting fears of a fresh bout of violent repression

item.title: Let's talk about reform, says Assad
item.description: Too little too late, say protesters as President Assad promises to end 48 years of emergency law by the end of the week and instigate further reforms. 'We want to engage in dialogue', the president says. Protests continue

item.title: Families flee Adjdabiya assault
item.description: Gaddafi's forces attack the key rebel-held town of Ajdabiya as the regime steps up efforts to regain eastern territory. Ajdabiya is situated at a strategic highway junction and has changed hands several times since the conflict began

item.title: Protests after women banned from rallies
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of people demonstrate across Yemen, denouncing President Saleh for saying women should not take part in rallies. At least 10 people were shot and wounded by government forces, doctors said

item.title: Shots fired at protesters in Homs
item.description: Syrian forces shoot dead eight protesters in Homs in clashes after the death of a jailed tribal leader. Shots and teargas are fired at crowds who defied authorities' warnings to halt what they called an insurrection

item.title: Minority Sunnis killed
item.description: At least 12 people believed to belong to Iran's Sunni minority have been killed in three days of clashes between security forces and anti-government protesters in the south-western city of Ahwaz

item.title: Emergency rule lifted
item.description: Syria's government approves the lifting of a draconian, 48-year-old emergency law in the biggest concession yet made by President Assad, after a month of unrest. Nonetheless, a day later Mahmoud Issa, a key opposition figure, is arrested

item.title: UK-French mission 'violates UN remit'
item.description: Libya says the Anglo-French decision to send military advisers to the Libyan opposition in Benghazi violates the UN remit; fears are voiced of mission creep. Some 20 children are reported killed by Libyan troops. Shelling of Misrata continues

item.title: Protesters killed in Yemen
item.description: At least three people are killed when police open fire on anti-government protesters in Sanaa and Taiz. The UN security council calls for restraint in its first discussion of the violence there

item.title: Photojournalists killed in Misrata
item.description: Tim Hetherington, a British-born photographer and Oscar-nominated documentary director, and Chris Hondros, a US photographer for Getty Images, are among at least 15 civilians killed when the besieged rebel stronghold of Misrata comes under heavy mortar fire

item.title: Mubarak's name removed from buildings
item.description: An Egyptian court orders the removal of Hosni Mubarak's name from all public facilities and institutions - the latest step in dismantling the ousted president's legacy will affect hundreds of schools, streets, squares and libraries

item.title: US approves use of drones
item.description: The White House approves the use of missile-armed Predator drones to help Nato target Colonel Gaddafi's forces. The UNHCR says 11,000 refugees fleeing heavy fighting have crossed from Libya's western mountains into Tunisia in the past 10 days

item.title: Claim of systematic attacks on doctors
item.description: Bahraini authorities have conducted a systematic campaign of attacks and arrests against medical workers who treated injured protesters during months of unrest in the Gulf kingdom, according to the US-based medical group Physicians for Human Rights

item.title: Bloodiest day yet
item.description: Syria endures its bloodiest day of protests yet. Tens of thousands demonstrate after Friday prayers for greater political freedom and an end to Ba'ath party rule. Security forces use live rounds and teargas, reportedly killing at least 88

item.title: Rebels retake Misrata buildings
item.description: Besieged rebels retake key buildings in Misrata. Government forces claim to have come under attack as they tried to retreat. Save the Children says children as young as eight have suffered sexual assaults, including rape, during the conflict

item.title: Inspector denies role in Tunisian immolation
item.description: Fedia Hamdi, the municipal inspector jailed for slapping street trader Mohamed Bouazizi who burned himself alive in protest, sparking the Arab spring protests tells the Observer she was wrongly imprisoned. A tribunal freed Hamdi last week

item.title: Two Syrian MPs resign
item.description: At least 12 mourners are killed when security forces fire on funerals for pro-democracy protesters after the bloodiest day yet of the uprising. Two politicians resign from parliament in protest at the government's use of lethal force

item.title: Government troops pound Misrata
item.description: Gaddafi's troops pound Misrata, hours after the regime claimed its forces had pulled back to let tribal leaders try to negotiate a political resolution, or unleash a 'bloody' assault. Kuwait is to contribute 110m to the rebels

item.title: President offers to quit in return for immunity
item.description: A defiant President Ali Abdullah Saleh warns he will not give in to a 'coup', a day after reportedly agreeing to quit within a month. Tens of thousands of people demonstrate in Sana'a, insisting Saleh must go now

item.title: Troops fire on Syrian mourners
item.description: Troops fire on mourners burying those killed in yesterday's unrest. Security forces mount checkpoints across the country amid reported mass arrests of opposition supporters. Activists say 120 died this weekend. The Foreign Office tells Britons to leave Syria

item.title: Nato 'trying to assassinate Gaddafi'
item.description: The Libyan government accuses Nato of trying to assassinate Muammar Gaddafi in violation of the UN security council resolution after two air strikes in three days at premises in Tripoli where he is believed to direct military strategy

item.title: Tanks deployed in Syria crackdown
item.description: The Syrian crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrations escalates, with tanks deployed for the first time; scores are reported killed and many more arrested. Deraa bears the brunt, with 3,000 troops said to be deployed. The US announces new sanctions

item.title: Troops kill 12 in Sana'a
item.description: Security forces fire on an anti-government demonstration by 100,000 people in Sana'a, killing 12 protesters, a doctor says. A civil disobedience campaign calling for President Saleh to quit closes shops, schools and government offices in cities nationwide

item.title: Syrian MPs resign in protest
item.description: Hundreds of ruling Ba'ath party MPs resign in protest at an increasingly bloody crackdown believed to have killed at least 500 pro-democracy protesters. A divided UN security council fails to agree on a statement condemning regime violence

item.title: Nato airstrike kills 12 rebels
item.description: A Nato airstrike kills 12 rebel fighters and injures three others in a friendly fire incident in Misrata, according to local doctors and one of the survivors

item.title: Protesters sentenced to death
item.description: Four anti-government protesters are sentenced to death by a military court over the killing of two policemen when violence erupted in Manama last month. Human rights activists say the men did not receive a fair trial

item.title: Syria protests reach Damascus
item.description: Thousands of Syrians defy a bloody government crackdown, braving gunfire from security forces to demonstrate in Damascus and nationwide. At least 42 are killed, mostly in besieged Deraa, where villagers tried to break through the security cordon

item.title: Troops storm Deraa mosque
item.description: The regime sends fresh troops to pound the besieged city of Deraa. Tanks and armoured personnel carriers are deployed and troops storm the Omari mosque, a hub for protesters, killing four people, including the imam's son, residents say

item.title: Rebels reject Gaddafi ceasefire offer
item.description: In a rambling TV address Gaddafi says he is 'sacred' to Libyans and calls for talks with Nato. Libyan opposition forces reject Gaddafi's ceasefire offer and dismiss regime claims that loyalist forces have cut off access to Misrata

item.title: Envoy expelled after UK embassy burns
item.description: The British embassy in Tripoli is burned and other western missions are ransacked by angry crowds in retaliation for a Nato air strike that killed members of Gaddafi's family. Britain responds by expelling Libya's ambassador to London

item.title: Dissidents rounded up
item.description: Scores of prominent intellectuals and activists go into hiding as government forces try to crush dissent by carrying out raids and arrests across the country

item.title: Misrata attacks block aid ships
item.description: Gaddafi's forces bombard Misrata, preventing humanitarian aid ships from entering for the fourth day. Rebels ask Nato for help. Crowds in Tripoli attend the funeral of Gaddafi's son and three grandchildren, killed in a Nato air strike

item.title: Arab leaders' Swiss assets frozen
item.description: The Swiss government says it has identified potential assets to be frozen worth 830m Swiss francs (nearly $1bn or 600m) belonging to Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi and the ousted presidents of Egypt and Tunisia

item.title: Regime seizes control of Banias
item.description: Syrian security forces seize control of the coastal city of Banias from demonstrators challenging the authoritarian rule of President Assad

item.title: Gaddafi regime 'committed war crimes'
item.description: The Gaddafi regime committed war crimes against pro-democracy demonstrators, opening fire 'systematically' on peaceful protesters, according to a report by the international criminal court prosecutor. Switzerland freezes 253m of Libyan leaders' assets

item.title: Anti-Assad protesters arrested
item.description: Hundreds of Syrian soldiers in combat gear break into houses and make arrests in Damascus, the scene of a mass demonstration last week demanding the removal of President Assad

item.title: Tripoli 'running out of fuel'
item.description: Riot police man Tripoli fuel pumps as queues form amid fears that petrol is running out. An official accuses the international community of 'trying to starve the Libyan people' by cutting supplies. Britain expels two more Libyan diplomats

item.title: 16 killed in 'day of defiance'
item.description: The Syrian regime's violent crackdown on protesters continues, with at least 16 killed during a 'day of defiance'. Many thousands turned out in 65 towns and cities across the country, according to activists

item.title: Government forces destroy Misrata rebels' fuel supply
item.description: Libyan government forces bomb four large oil tanks in Misrata, destroying the city's only source of fuel, according to rebels

item.title: Tanks fire on protesters
item.description: Syrian tanks enter the Mediterranean coastal town of Banias and open fire on demonstrators

item.title: 12 dead in religious clashes
item.description: Muslim-Christian clashes in Cairo leave 12 dead and cast a cloud over hopes for peaceful transition. The government swiftly announces compensation for the dead and injured and strict implementation of new laws banning gatherings outside places of worship

item.title: Aircraft carrier 'left migrants to die'
item.description: Dozens of African migrants who boarded a boat in Tripoli for the Italian island of Lampedusa were left to die in the Mediterranean after European military units apparently ignored their cries for help, the Guardian has learned

item.title: Tunisia reinstates night curfew
item.description: Tunisia reinstates an emergency night-time curfew after four days of clashes between police and anti-government protesters. Iman al-Obeidi, the Libyan who claimed she was raped by Gaddafi's soldiers, reportedly flees to Tunisia, helped by a defecting officer

item.title: EU spares President Assad
item.description: The EU imposes an arms embargo and other sanctions on Syria, but does not penalise Assad personally. Tanks enter Homs; hundreds are arrested and troops are seen in Damascus suburbs. Western diplomats say Iran is assisting the crackdown

item.title: Lebanese police send Syrians back
item.description: Syrians attempting to flee across the Lebanese border to escape the violent regime clampdown are being rounded up and returned to an uncertain fate by Lebanese security forces, according to local residents

item.title: Bahraini protesters sacked
item.description: Bahrain's oil company has sacked almost 300 employees for taking part in anti-government protests and general strikes in recent weeks, the energy minister says

item.title: Yemeni troops kill protesters
item.description: Yemeni forces open fire on demonstrators in three cities, killing at least 18 and wounding hundreds in one of the fiercest bouts of violence witnessed in nearly three months of unrest aimed at toppling President Saleh

item.title: Gaddafi back on Libyan TV
item.description: Libyan state television shows footage of Gaddafi meeting officials in a Tripoli hotel, ending two weeks of doubt over his fate since a Nato air strike killed his son. The US invites Libyan rebels for White House talks

item.title: Six killed in Syria protests
item.description: Six people are killed as protesters continue to defy a government crackdown. Hilary Clinton leads international condemnation of the violence and Britain calls in the Syrian ambassador

item.title: Egyptians return to Tahrir Square
item.description: Tens of thousands of Egyptians return to Tahrir Square in a show of national unity against sectarian tension, and in support of the Palestinians. Suzanne Mubarak, the ousted president's wife, is detained on suspicion of illegally acquiring wealth

item.title: Nato accused of 'slaying' imams
item.description: Libyan officials accuse Nato of 'barbarically slaying' 11 imams by bombing a guest house in Brega where they had gathered. Gaddafi gives an audio address to rebut rumours he has been injured in an air strike

item.title: Christian protesters attacked
item.description: The head of Egypt's Coptic Orthodox church urges followers to end a week-long sit-in in Cairo after a mob attacks Christian protesters and their supporters, injuring 78. Christians have faced attacks by Muslim fundamentalists since Mubarak was ousted

item.title: Israel kills Palestinian protesters
item.description: Potential new flashpoints in the Middle East unrest open after Israel opens fire on pro-Palestinian protesters on its borders with Syria and Lebanon, killing more than 12 people and drawing furious condemnation from Damascus

item.title: Koussa 'helping Nato to target Gaddafi'
item.description: A network of Libyan defectors, including the former regime stalwart Moussa Koussa, are passing information to Nato to help it destroy Muammar Gaddafi's military sites, including key bunker complexes, according to senior officials in Libya

item.title: Saudi diplomat shot dead in Pakistan
item.description: Saudi diplomat Hassan al-Khatani is killed by gunmen on motorcycles in Karachi, four days after a grenade attack on Karachi's Saudi consulate. Some speculate the attacks are reprisals for Bin Laden's death or linked to upheaval in Bahrain

item.title: ICC names Gaddafis as war crimes suspects
item.description: Gaddafi, his son Saif al-Islam and intelligence chief Abdullah Senussi are named as war crimes suspects by the chief prosecutor for the international criminal court. Britain increases strikes on what it says are secret police compounds in Tripoli

item.title: Claims that oil minister has defected
item.description: Tripoli refuses to deny claims that the oil minister, Shukri Ghanem, has fled to Tunisia in the second high-profile defection since the air campaign began. Nato denies Libyan reports that an alliance warship has been struck off Misrata

item.title: Mass grave found near Deraa
item.description: Thirteen bodies have been retrieved from a mass grave in Deraa, the hub of Syria's protest movement, according to residents who told human rights organisations that hundreds are unaccounted for since the crackdown began on 18 March

item.title: Security forces 'made mistakes'
item.description: Assad says security forces have made mistakes, blaming poorly trained police at least partially for a crackdown that has killed 850. Activists say eight more people have died in Tel Kelakh, bombarded by tanks for a fourth day

item.title: Gaddafi's wife and daughter 'have fled'
item.description: Muammar Gaddafi's wife and daughter, Safia and Aisha, crossed over the border into Tunisia several days ago, according to a Tunisian security source

item.title: US and EU sanctions target Assad
item.description: The US and EU impose sanctions on President Assad for the first time in response to his brutal crackdown on pro-democracy protests. Sanctions earlier this month stopped short of targeting Assad personally

item.title: Bin Laden praises Arab Spring uprisings
item.description: A tape recorded by Osama bin Laden is released posthumously onto Islamist militant websites. It praises the Arab protest movements and predicts they will spread. 'The light of the revolution came from Tunisia... What are you waiting for?'

item.title: RAF sinks Gaddafi's warships
item.description: All fighting ships of the Libyan navy are sunk or severely damaged by RAF jets in a night-time raid on Tripoli and Al Khums that Nato says has crippled the ability of Muammar Gaddafi's forces to lay mines

item.title: A 'new chapter' in US diplomacy
item.description: Barack Obama promises a 'new chapter' in US diplomacy, outlining an Israel-Palestine deal based on pre-1967 boundaries and endorsing uprisings in Egypt, Tunisia, Libya, Syria and, for the first time, US ally Bahrain. No mention of Saudi Arabia

item.title: Huge protests in Yemen
item.description: President Saleh calls for early elections as thousands rally against his 30-year rule. There is also a pro-Saleh counter-demonstration. Saleh has twice backed out of a Gulf Arab-brokered transition deal, and some say his announcement is a ploy

item.title: Missing photographer 'killed in desert'
item.description: Relatives of South African photographer Anton Hammerl say they believe he was killed in the desert by Gaddafi's forces. The wounded Hammerl was initially reported captured with Americans Clare Morgana Gillis and James Foley, who were later released

item.title: Security forces kill three protesters in Homs
item.description: Security forces fire on protesters in Homs, killing at least three, and elsewhere; some reports say more than 20 died nationwide, a day after Obama urged Assad to lead the democratic transition 'or get out of the way'

item.title: Saleh refuses to quit
item.description: President Saleh refuses to sign a deal arranging for him to leave office in return for legal immunity. His supporters trap western and Arab diplomats, including the British ambassador, inside an embassy in Sana'a for several hours

item.title: EU sanctions target Assad
item.description: The European Union imposes sanctions on President Assad and other senior officials, raising pressure on his government to end weeks of violence against protesters. Sanctions earlier this month stopped short of targeting Assad personally

item.title: 38 killed in gun battles
item.description: Up to 50 are killed in two days of gun battles in Sana'a between security forces loyal to President Saleh and guards from Yemen's most powerful tribal federation whose leader backs protesters' demands for Saleh to quit

item.title: Nato hits Tripoli in heaviest bombing yet
item.description: Nato warplanes bombard targets in Tripoli with more than 20 air strikes, hitting the area around Muammar Gaddafi's residential compound in what appears to be the heaviest night of bombing yet in the city

item.title: Mubarak charged with murder
item.description: Egypt refers Hosni Mubarak to court over the killing of protesters and other charges, defying speculation that Egypt's new military rulers would spare the former president public humiliation. His two sons also face charges

item.title: President refuses to quit
item.description: President Saleh says he will not quit or let Yemen become a 'failed state', as clashes continue in Sana'a for a third day; at least 50 have died and residents flee. The US tells its citizens to leave

item.title: Blogger minister quits
item.description: Slim Amamou, the blogger who was arrested and accused of dissident cyber activity during the January revolution, quits his post as minister for youth and sport, to which he was appointed after the uprising ousted President Ben Ali

item.title: Britain to deploy Apache helicopters
item.description: UK ministers are set to announce the deployment of Apache attack helicopters to Libya, a move seen as a significant escalation of Britain's role in the conflict despite government denials, according to well-placed Whitehall sources

item.title: Regime peace offer sidelines Gaddafi
item.description: Libya's regime offers to talk to rebels, move towards constitutional government and compensate victims. The US and EU are sceptical. Gaddafi's name is conspicuously absent as MI6 reports he is increasingly paranoid and on the run

item.title: Eight killed in crackdown
item.description: Eight people are killed in Friday protests in towns across Syria, according to Damascus-based lawyer and human rights monitor Razan Zeitouneh

item.title: Tribal leader calls ceasefire
item.description: Tribal leader Sadeq al-Ahmar announces a ceasefire between his Hashid tribe and forces loyal to President Saleh and tells supporters he backs a peaceful uprising. A tribal militia seizes two army bases outside Sana'a, prompting government air strikes

item.title: G8 pledges $20bn loans
item.description: G8 leaders pledge $20bn (12bn) of loans and aid to Tunisia and Egypt over two years and suggest more will be available if the countries continue on the path to democracy. 100,000 gather in Cairo's Tahrir Square

item.title: Egypt opens Gaza border crossing
item.description: New government allows first free passage out of blockaded territory in four years as part of reconciliation deal brokered between Hamas and Fatah. Opening the Rafah crossing flags a more sympathetic Egyptian attitude towards Gaza since Mubarak's fall

item.title: UK jets in rare daytime strike on Tripoli
item.description: British RAF jets take part in a rare daytime strike by Nato aircraft on Tripoli, destroying the guard towers at Muammar Gaddafi's compound

item.title: Britain training Saudi national guard
item.description: Britain is training Saudi Arabia's national guard the elite force deployed against Bahrain's protesters in public order enforcement and the use of sniper rifles, despite classifying Riyadh's human rights record as 'a major concern'

item.title: Zinjibar 'under Islamist control'
item.description: A key coastal city deserted by security forces is under Islamist militant control, residents say. Critics accuse President Saleh of letting militants seize Zinjibar to distract from protests by his opponents. Saleh claims al-Qaida will thrive without him

item.title: 11 killed in push into central Syria
item.description: Troops kill at least 11 civilians in a push into central Syria, a human rights campaigner says. Residents say tanks fired heavy machineguns in Talbiseh and Rastan. Official media say four security forces members were killed in Talbiseh

item.title: Soldiers storm protest camp, killing 20
item.description: Hundreds of soldiers loyal to President Saleh storm a protest camp in Taiz and fire on crowds indiscriminately, killing at least 20 people, according to medical officials and witnesses. Some reports say as many as 50 were killed

item.title: Foreign special forces 'on the frontline'
item.description: Al-Jazeera films six armed westerners on the frontline with rebels in the first apparent confirmation of foreign special forces' involvement. Eight more senior Libyan officials defect to Italy; Gaddafi attends 'truce' talks with South Africa's Jacob Zuma

item.title: Seven killed as ceasefire collapses
item.description: The ceasefire between Hashid tribesmen and President Saleh's troops collapses: at least 10 people are reported killed in Sana'a and Taiz. The UN condemns the use of force against protesters: up to 50 have reportedly died since Sunday

item.title: Teenage victim becomes revolution symbol
item.description: Hamza al-Khatib, 13, becomes the most famous victim yet of Syria's uprising. He was arrrested on 29 April and on 27 May his badly mutilated corpse was released to his horrified family, who were warned to keep silent

item.title: 41 dead in street battles
item.description: At least 41 people die in shelling and street battles between government forces and rebels in Sana'a. Army defectors said presidential guard units shelled the HQ of an army brigade whose commander was rumoured to want to defect

item.title: 13 killed as government shells Rastan
item.description: Thirteen people die when government forces shell the central town of Rastan. Nearby Talbisa is reportedly besieged by tanks, helicopters and snipers. Opposition groups dismiss an announcement of a conditional amnesty under which some detainees would be freed

item.title: Fury as Vodafone claims revolution role
item.description: Vodafone faces a backlash over an advert suggesting its 'Our Power' campaign helped inspire Egypt's revolution. Many pro-change activists blame Vodafone and other mobile phone companies for following government orders and implementing a communications blackout during the revolution

item.title: Saleh survives assassination bid
item.description: President Saleh survives an apparent assassination attempt - an attack on a mosque in his compound. The government blames Hamid al-Ahmar of the opposition Islah party for the attack and government forces shell his mansion in Sana'a

item.title: Safe' Bahrain gets grand prix go-ahead
item.description: Bahrain is granted permission to stage the delayed grand prix, drawing condemnation from human rights groups. Jean Todt, president of motor sport's world governing body, insists: 'The situation is very peaceful in Bahrain. You should go and look'

item.title: British Apaches in first attack
item.description: British army Apache helicopters attack Muammar Gaddafi's troops for the first time, destroying a radar station and a military checkpoint and marking a sharp escalation in Nato's Libya campaign

item.title: Syrian forces kill at least 100
item.description: Syrian forces kill at least 100 protesters in two of the bloodiest days since the start of the uprising, according to activists. Tens of thousands marched in defiance of security forces. Internet access is cut

item.title: Egypt agrees $3bn IMF loan
item.description: Egypt's interim government agrees a $3bn loan package with the International Monetary Fund to help stabilise the country's finances during the post-Mubarak transition period

item.title: Stand down, west urges Saleh
item.description: The US and Britain urge Saudi Arabia to persuade President Saleh to formally stand down after flying to Riyadh for treatment for injuries sustained in an attack in Sana'a

item.title: 20 reported killed in Golan clashes
item.description: Israeli troops clash with protesters on the Syrian border for the second time in three weeks, with several dozen reported injured and claims of up to 20 dead. The Golan area of Syria is off-limits without state permission

item.title: Medics on trial for treating protesters
item.description: 47 doctors and nurses who treated injured anti-government protesters during the unrest go on trial in a security court accused of participating in efforts to overthrow the monarchy

item.title: Baby 'air strike victim' hurt in car crash
item.description: A hospital worker reveals that a baby 'air strike victim' was in fact injured in a car crash. Rebel fighters in Misrata lose gains made against Gaddafi's forces after Nato instruction to pull back ahead of air strikes

item.title: President's injuries 'extensive'
item.description: President Saleh suffered 'extensive' injuries including severe burns in the attack on his Sana'a palace, reducing the chances that he will be able to return home after treatment in Saudi Arabia. Aides initially claimed his injuries were minor

item.title: Government claims 120 security forces killed
item.description: The Syrian government vows retaliation after claiming 120 of its security forces were killed in attacks in and around Jisr al-Shughour. The opposition disputes the claims, which could not be independently verified. A prominent lesbian blogger is kidnapped

item.title: Royal Marines 'on standby' for evacuation
item.description: Royal Marines are on standby off the Yemeni coast, ready to assist in any evacuation of Britons. The MoD insists this is 'part of routine deployment'. The Foreign Office has advised Britons to leave while commercial flights continue

item.title: Government denies reports about attack on King Abdullah
item.description: Official line squashes reports of royal convoy being hit by stones and bottles during a visit to town of Tafila, scene of previous anti-government protests, despite eyewitness accounts to the contrary

item.title: General election delayed until October
item.description: Democratic enthusiasm persists as election is postponed to give participants more time to prepare and, with almost 400,000 potential voters not registered, the electoral committee time to update the electoral register

item.title: Six months on: After Ben Ali - video
item.description: Six months after the fall of the Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali regime, Tunisians discuss their efforts to implement radical change in the face of enormous challenges - both social and political

item.title: Ben Ali sentenced to 35 years in jail
item.description: Former Tunisian president and his wife sentenced to 35 years in jail after being found guilty of theft in absentia by a Tunisian court

item.title: Ahmadinejad allies arrested
item.description: Iran's former deputy foreign minister, Muhammad Sharif Malekzadeh, and two other senior allies of Pesident Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, are arrested on charges of financial corruption in a growing rift between the hardline president and Ayatollah Ali Khamenei

item.title: Islamist party leader speaks out against delaying elections
item.description: Rached Ghannouchi, the leader of Tunisia's largest party, accuses former elite of 'trying to escape the ballot box' and cautions that further delays to general election could endanger the revolution's gains

item.title: Syrian activist talks sanctioned
item.description: Authorities apparently allow 150 Syrian activists to meet in Damascus to discuss the crisis. The American man behind the Gay Girl in Damascus blog hoax is accused of creating another Arab female online identity to defend himself

item.title: ICC issues arrest warrant for Gaddafi
item.description: The international criminal court issues arrest warrants for Muammar Gaddafi, his son and intelligence chief over crimes against humanity committed against opponents of the regime. Libyan rebels say they have advanced to within 50 miles of Tripoli

item.title: Conscripts 'ordered to fire on unarmed protesters'
item.description: A Syrian army conscript who defected to Turkey tells the Guardian troops were ordered to fire on unarmed protesters in Deraa; he says 100 were killed each week and he saw no armed protesters in a month

item.title: Women arrested for defying driving ban
item.description: At least five Saudi women are arrested after defying the ban on women drivers, an activist says. For two weeks Saudi women have been driving through Riyadh and other cities in a challenge to the ban

item.title: Diplomat 'intimidated Syrians in UK'
item.description: Syria's ambassador to Britain is called into the Foreign Office and warned about allegations that a diplomat at the embassy has been intimidating Syrians living in the UK

item.title: France armed rebel fighters
item.description: Nato is reviewing the conduct of its military campaign in Libya after France admitted arming rebel fighters for the advance on Tripoli in apparent defiance of the UN mandate

item.title: King orders investigation of crackdown
item.description: Bahrain's king orders an independent fact-finding mission to establish whether protesters' human rights were abused during a violent crackdown on anti-government unrest. He says he is committed to reform but blames protesters for the 'state of chaos'

item.title: Troops withdraw from Hama
item.description: The Syrian army moves out of Hama to the surprise of activists and diplomats, a move celebrated by residents as a victory after one of the worst bouts of bloodshed there

item.title: 1,000 hurt in street clashes
item.description: 1,000 are injured in the fiercest fighting in Cairo since Mubarak fell. Violence erupted after the former interior minister's trial on the charge of unlawfully killing protesters was delayed. The next day protesters' tents return to Tahrir Square

item.title: Syria 'roadmap' would leave Assad in power
item.description: Details emerge of a controversial reform 'roadmap' that would leave President Assad power despite demands for his overthrow. Washington denies it endorses the plan. The US criticises Iran for supporting the Syrian crackdown and increases sanctions on Tehran

item.title: Iranian film-maker detained in notorious Tehran prison
item.description: Unidentified officials arrest documentary maker and women's rights activist Mahnaz Mohammadi at her home, two weeks after another women's rights campaigner and photojournalist, Maryam Majd, was also detained

item.title: Referendum backs king's reform agenda
item.description: Moroccans vote overwhelmingly unbelievably, democracy campaigners say to adopt a new constitution championed by the king as an answer to demands for greater freedoms, but which protesters say will still leave the monarch firmly in control

item.title: Biggest day of protests
item.description: The US increases pressure on President Assad to implement 'genuine reforms' after the biggest day of national protest. Demonstrators say at least 24 died on 'the Friday of Departure'. In Hama 200,000 demonstrate and the governor is sacked

item.title: Iran state TV censors Ahmadinejad video clip
item.description: State broadcaster edits out Iranian president's speech attacking recent arrests of his close allies as power struggle with the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, continues. Ahmadinejad retorts by publishing full version of the video on his official website

item.title: Reconciliation talks begin
item.description: Reconciliation talks between Bahrain's Sunni-led government and the majority Shia opposition open in Manama after four months of anti-regime protests. The main Shia opposition party, Al Wefaq, decided at the last minute to join the government-led talks

item.title: Western powers are 'legitimate targets'
item.description: Western powers attacking Libya have made themselves 'legitimate targets' for retaliation, Gaddafi's son Saif says. He rejects rebels' calls for his father to quit as the price of peace. 'We will never surrender,' he tells French TV

item.title: Protests as court frees police suspects
item.description: Hundreds scuffle with security guards in a Cairo court after a judge orders the release of 10 police officers charged with killing protesters. Only one policeman has been convicted, in absentia, over 800+ deaths in a government crackdown

item.title: Tanks re-enter Hama
item.description: Residents of Hama erect roadblocks in an unsuccessful attempt to stop tanks and armoured columns re-entering, five days after the largest anti-regime demonstration yet in the four-month uprising. At least 22 people are reportedly killed in two days

item.title: Libyan rebels in two-pronged offensive
item.description: Libyan rebels launch an apparently co-ordinated two-pronged offensive against pro-Gaddafi forces, striking from bases in the western mountains south-west of Tripoli and from the besieged city of Misrata, 130 miles to the east

item.title: Saleh's first appearance since assassination bid
