item.description: President Saleh criticises opponents in his first public appearance since June's assassination attempt. Bandaged and looking weakened, Saleh blames 'terrorist elements' for the attack and - without naming any particular groups says dialogue is the only solution

item.title: Gaddafi threatens attacks on Europe
item.description: Muammar Gaddafi threatens to send hundreds of Libyans to launch attacks in Europe in revenge for the Nato-led military campaign against him

item.title: Egypt's PM promises to meet protesters' demands
item.description: Interim PM Sharaf pledges to 'meet the people's demands' after mass rallies accusing army generals of betrayal. He says police accused of killing protesters will be sacked and promises speedy trials of Mubarak officials. Activists dismiss 'empty rhetoric'

item.title: Activists boycott 'dialogue' with regime
item.description: Syrian activists boycott a 'dialogue' meeting with the regime in Damascus as defectors say they were ordered to fire on unarmed protesters. Activists say security forces have killed two people in a raid on the city of Homs

item.title: Assad supporters storm French and US embassies
item.description: French embassy guards in Damascus fire live ammunition to disperse Assad loyalists who tried to break into the compound in protest at the envoy's visit to the opposition stronghold of Hama. The US embassy faces a similar break-in

item.title: Egyptian pipeline hit in fourth attack
item.description: A large explosion hits Egypt's main gas pipeline through the Sinai, cutting supplies to Israel and Jordan for the fourth time this year. Campaigners say a controversial 2008 export deal enabled Israel to buy gas at below-market prices

item.title: Rebels accuses of looting and torching
item.description: Libyan rebel forces looted shops, homes and medical facilities in several towns they seized in the western mountains, Human Rights Watch says. The group says rebels torched homes believed to belong to Gaddafi supporters. Rebels retake Qawalish

item.title: Egypt postpones election
item.description: Democratic parliamentary elections could be postponed from September to November, amid a standoff between the ruling military council and protesters who believe their revolution is being betrayed. Demonstrators surge out of Tahrir Square towards nearby parliament buildings

item.title: Libyan rebels win political recognition
item.description: Rebels win broad political recognition as Libya's 'legitimate authority' and the promise of huge financial support and a British commitment to intensify Nato bombing at an Istanbul meeting of the international 'contact group'

item.title: 19 die in day of protest
item.description: Activists say at least 19 people died nationwide, including seven in Damascus, as up to a million protest. Heavy clashes took place in Damascus; other flashpoints are Aleppo, Deraa, Idleb and Homs. Syrian officials again blame armed gangs

item.title: Ministers sacked in response to protests
item.description: Prime minister Essam Sharaf sacks top ministers to try to quell protests against his government's legitimacy. Zahi Hawass, antiquities minister and TV celebrity tainted by his praise for Mubarak, goes, as do finance, industry, education and foreign ministers

item.title: Syria endures bloodiest weekend
item.description: Syria endures one of its bloodiest weekends since the uprising began. In Homs more than 30 people are reported killed in 24 hours, according to a human rights group

item.title: Rebels enter Brega
item.description: Libyan rebels backed by powerful Nato air strikes fight their way into parts of the government-held oil town of Brega in one of their most ambitious offensives of the war so far

item.title: US and Libya in first direct talks
item.description: The US and Libya hold their first direct talks since the conflict began, but disagree about what happens next. 'We support any peace initiative, as long as they don't decide Libya's future from outside,' a Libyan spokesman says

item.title: Mourners killed at Homs funeral
item.description: Troops and militiamen loyal to President Assad kill 16 people in Homs. Concern is mounting that events there are becoming dangerously sectarian; today's dead include three mourners at a funeral for 10 people killed yesterday

item.title: Libyan rebels push towards Zlitan
item.description: Libyan rebels, supported by Nato air strikes, claim significant advances against Gaddafi's forces in a two-day assault. Rebels in Misrata say they captured the chief of operations in Zlitan, General Abdul Nabih Zayid, after overrunning his command post

item.title: Huge anti-regime demonstrations
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Syrians turn out for anti-regime demonstrations across the country with at least 11 people reported killed by security forces and tensions mounting in the run-up to Ramadan

item.title: Crackdown ahead of Ramadan
item.description: Troops backed by tanks enter the village of Sarjeh, cutting electricity and water and making arrests, activists say. Detentions in Damascus and troop reinforcements in Homs are also reported as President Assad tries to quash dissent before Ramadan

item.title: Dozens injured during Cairo protest
item.description: Strained relations between activists and military rulers worsen after dozens of protesters are attacked during a rally in Cairo by unidentified assailants who appeared to be sympathetic to the ruling generals, a pillar of the old regime

item.title: Opposition rejects 'empty gesture' on political parties
item.description: Syria's cabinet backs a draft law to allow rival political parties to the ruling Ba'ath party for the first time in decades. Opposition groups largely dismiss the move as an empty gesture

item.title: Britain says Gaddafi could stay in Libya
item.description: Britain is prepared to agree to a political settlement that would see Muammar Gaddafi remain in Libya after relinquishing his hold on power, the foreign secretary, William Hague, says

item.title: 20 die as troops target Damascus
item.description: Around 20 people are killed as security forces launch raids against suspected anti-government protesters in and around Damascus. Activists said locals tried to stop the advance by throwing stones and burning tyres. Two 10-year-olds were among those killed

item.title: Britain recognises rebel regime
item.description: Britain confers diplomatic recognition on the Libyan rebels' National Transitional Council, gives it 91m in frozen oil funds and expels pro-Gaddafi embassy staff. Rebels in Misrata say they have rescued 105 kidnapped civilians from behind enemy lines

item.title: Iran releases prominent actor and filmmaker
item.description: Pegah Ahangarani and Mahnaz Mohammadi released on bail after widespread criticism of a crackdown on artists and activists

item.title: Syrian protesters reject support from al-Qaida leader
item.description: Syrian activists reject a message from al-Qaida's new leader, Ayman al-Zawahiri, praising their efforts to topple Bashar al-Assad as an Islamic battle against US and Israeli interests. A human rights group says 2,918 people have been 'forcibly disappeared'

item.title: Rebel army leader Abdel Fatah Younis killed
item.description: The rebels' chief of staff, Abdel Fatah Younis, is killed; rebel authorities initially claim he was assassinated by pro-Gaddafi agents. Until the uprising Younis was Gaddafi's interior minister and confidant. When riots hit Benghazi he dramatically switched sides

item.title: Nato bombs Libyan TV transmitters
item.description: Nato says its warplanes have bombed Libyan state TV satellite transmitters in Tripoli in an attempt to stem the incitement of violence against those not loyal to Muammar Gaddafi

item.title: Islamist militia killed anti-Gaddafi leader
item.description: Efforts by insurgents to topple Gaddafi are in disarray after a senior Libyan opposition figure admits that rebel Islamist-linked militia within anti-Gaddafi forces were responsible for the murder of their most senior army commander, General Abdel Fatah Younis

item.title: Air strike kills tribal allies
item.description: Government air strikes targeting Islamist militants in southern Yemen accidentally kill 14 allied tribesmen in a further deterioration of the security situation. Government forces and armed tribesmen have been battling to expel militants who have seized towns

item.title: Assad's troops massacre 100 in Hama
item.description: President Assad follows in his father's footsteps and sends in tanks to end a month-long siege by protesters in Hama, smashing though makeshift barricades just after dawn on the eve of Ramadan and killing up to 100 people

item.title: Troops retake Tahrir Square
item.description: Egypt's army violently retakes Tahrir Square , firing into the air as tanks move in. The square has been occupied for more than three weeks by demonstrators who accuse the ruling generals of dragging their feet on reform

item.title: Rebels enter Zlitan after RAF assault
item.description: Rebels enter Zlitan after a weekend of heavy fighting in which Nato escalated its bombing in the run-up to Ramadan. RAF planes dropped 16 Paveway laser-guided bombs in two days, destroying government tanks and clearing the rebels' path

item.title: Protesters attacked in Hama and Damascus
item.description: Security forces continue to attack civilian protesters in Hama and Damascus, reportedly killing 28 in two days. The EU imposes sanctions on key regime figures and the UN struggles to agree to condemn the violence

item.title: Mubarak in the dock
item.description: Mubarak is stretchered into court as his trial begins on charges of economic corruption, striking an illegal business deal and the unlawful killing of protesters. He denies all charges. If convicted, he could face the death penalty

item.title: Gaddafi's son declares allegiance to Islamists
item.description: The one-time alternative face of Gaddafi's regime, his son, Saif al-Islam, declares allegiance to Islamists whom he had previously branded as lead-conspirators in the rebellion. He suggests Libya could emerge from civil war as an Islamic state

item.title: Massacre in Hamas
item.description: Amid a media blackout, citizen journalism organisation Avaaz says 109 people are killed in Hama in one day. Fleeing residents describe corpses lying unburied for fear of government snipers. Democracy campaigners spurn an Assad decree permitting opposition parties

item.title: Mubarak's puppet trade union federation dismantled
item.description: An Egyptian trade union federation that was used by the government to repress labour activism is dissolved, dismantling another powerful component of Hosni Mubarak's dictatorship

item.title: Syrians express outrage over Hama massacre
item.description: Crowds protest against Assad's regime and declare support for Hama, where 200 residents have reportedly been killed since Sunday. Troops fire on crowds after Friday prayers, killing at least 13. In Hama, tanks resume shelling of residential districts

item.title: Troops attack Houleh and Deir Ezzor
item.description: Security forces attack the central town of Houleh and parts of Deir Ezzor in the east, killing at least four, activists say. A day earlier Syria's foreign minister promised free parliamentary elections by the end of the year

item.title: President Saleh leaves hospital
item.description: President Saleh leaves hospital in Saudi Arabia, more than two months after being wounded in an attack on his palace in Sana'a. He is recuperating in Riyadh. His absence has added to the turmoil in Yemen

item.title: The repression is getting worse'
item.description: The Guardian's Ian Black returns to Bahrain months after its brief exposure to the Arab spring, and finds that the cat-and-mouse routine of protest and repression continues

item.title: Saudi king demands end to bloodshed
item.description: Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah demands an end to the bloodshed in Syria and recalls his country's ambassador from Damascus, in a rare case of one of the Arab world's most powerful leaders intervening against another

item.title: Turkish foreign minister urges end to crackdown
item.description: Envoys from Turkey, India, Brazil and South Africa head to Damascus to press President Assad to end the violent crackdown. Today's visit by Turkey's foreign minister, Ahmet Davutoglu, is significant because the two countries were close until recently

item.title: Protesters plan 'day of not kneeling'
item.description: Seven people are reported killed in raids after tanks entered Qusayr and three in Deir Ezzor. The opposition says 257 have died in the latest 11-day-old crackdown. Protesters call for mass demonstrations - a 'day of not kneeling'

item.title: Crackdown spreads to Aleppo
item.description: Syria's uprising spreads into the commercial hub and regime stronghold of Aleppo, where two people die during rare government raids. At least 13 protesters are killed in other towns. Hillary Clinton calls for a boycott of Syria

item.title: Assad orders tanks into rebel towns
item.description: Syrian tanks and gunmen sweep through two towns to root out anti-government protesters amid heavy firing that has sent many fleeing to safer areas. At least three are reportedly killed

item.title: Rebels claim Tripoli advance
item.description: Rebels claim to be advancing on Tripoli on three fronts, Zawiya, Ghariyan and Tawarga, cutting supply lines and meeting only sporadic resistance. A government spokesman denies reports that it is holding talks in Tunisia with rebels

item.title: Gunboats pound port city of Latakia
item.description: Syria uses gunboats for the first time to crush the uprising. At least 19 people die in Latakia when machine guns are fired from a ship and armoured vehicles at the neighbourhood of Ramel, residents say

item.title: Gaddafi: get ready for the fight
item.description: Gaddafi urges his people to 'liberate Libya' from Nato. His speech, broadcast by state television, was his first since rebels launched their latest offensive: 'Get ready for the fight. The blood of martyrs is fuel for the battlefield'

item.title: Mubarak back in court
item.description: Hosni Mubarak and his two sons return to court to face charges of corruption and unlawful killing of protesters. Clashes erupt outside; a judge rules the trial will no longer be televised, prompting fears Mubarak may escape justice

item.title: Palestinians flee Latakia camp
item.description: 5,000 Palestinian refugees flee a camp in Latakia after Assad's forces attacked the port city, the UN says. Activists say at least six people were killed, bringing the civilian death toll there to 34, including a two-year-old girl

item.title: Regime ignores protests over siege of Latakia
item.description: The Assad regime continues to attack city amid calls from Turkey and regional states for a halt to shelling and the withdrawal of forces

item.title: Interior minister arrives in Egypt
item.description: Nasser al-Mabrouk Abdullah arrives in Cairo in what looks like the highest-ranking defection for months. Rebels claim near-control of Zawiya (although government troops retained its oil refinery). Gaddafi's forces reportedly launch their first Scud missile

item.title: Israelis killed in attacks near Egyptian border
item.description: Gunmen attack a bus carrying soldiers, a car and a military patrol near the southern resort of Eilat. The ambush fuels concerns that Egyptian security forces are losing control of the Sinai border region after the fall of Mubarak

item.title: UN names Syrian regime figures who could face ICC
item.description: Human rights investigators list Assad officials who could be prosecuted by the international criminal court for crimes committed against civilians during the crackdown. The move comes despite the president's claim to have halted operations in Latakia and Homs

item.title: Zawiya oil refinery falls to rebels
item.description: Advance on Tripoli continues to gather pace as rebels celebrate milestone of control over coastal highway and capital's petrol supply

item.title: Obama says Assad must resign
item.description: EU leaders echo rebuke, delivered by US president in executive order imposing sanctions and freezing assets

item.title: Israel and Gaza trade missile and rocket fire
item.description: Air strikes launched on Gaza and rockets fired into Israel as violence escalates after incident, near Eilat, which Israel blames on Palestinian militants

item.title: Ceasefire talks intensify as Israeli air strikes on Gaza continue
item.description: Efforts to end attack and counter-attack cycle continue as UN-backed Egyptian brokers seek to persuade Palestinian militants to halt violence. Meanwhile, the Israeli prime minister orders air strikes to continue as long as rockets are fired from Gaza

item.title: Assad forces storm Homs
item.description: As president defies international calls to step down, residents of Syria's third city report gunfire in a prison and hospital, and fear a full-scale assault as tanks mass outside

item.title: Protesters greet UN delegation with SOS signs
item.description: Government's attempts to whitewash evidence of brutal crackdown on uprising appear to backfire as humanitarian group is met by hundreds of demonstrators in Homs

item.title: Hundreds of rebel fighters enter Tripoli
item.description: The capital appears poised to fall as rebels enter Green Square and the NTC claims to have captured one of Gaddafi's sons, Saif al-Islam. Apparently still controlling his own compound, the dictator himself appeals for help on TV

item.title: Opposition moves towards setting up national council
item.description: Splits remain in opposition fragmented by sectarian and ideological tensions, with no clear next steps beyond demands for more freedom

item.title: Saif al-Islam Gaddafi makes reappearance
item.description: As fighting rages and the hunt for his father continues, Gaddafi's second son and heir presumptive confounds reports of his capture and makes defiant vow to chase the 'rats' out of Tripoli

item.title: Gaddafi vows 'martyrdom or victory' as rebels take compound
item.description: Ousted leader flees as opposition fighters swarm into his fortified citadel. A day of heavy fighting concludes with images of rebels stamping on a gilded bronze head of Gaddafi and setting fire to his famous tent

item.title: Political cartoonist beaten by regime forces
item.description: Ali Ferzat, a famous cultural figure in the Arab world who had become increasingly critical of Assad's regime, is found bleeding on Damascus roadside as government forces continue campaign to quash dissent

item.title: Gaddafi: 'Don't leave Tripoli ever to those rats destroy them'
item.description: With his whereabouts still unknown and opposition fighters attempting to flush out pockets of resistance from his supporters, Muammar Gaddafi urges supporters to march on Tripoli and rid the capital of rebels

item.title: Rebels move interim government to Tripoli
item.description: In its first Tripoli press conference, the National Transitional Council says its cabinet will be moving from Benghazi to the capital

item.title: Prominent Iranian activist missing after arrest
item.description: Human rights groups express concern over the fate of Kouhyar Goudarzi who was arrested, along with his mother, in July by plainclothes security forces. Iranian officials have so far refused to acknowledge they are holding him

item.title: Fighting stops in Gaza but fears of further violence remain
item.description: Egypt brokers second ceasefire in attempt to stop all-out war after more than a week of Israeli air strikes on targets in Gaza and rocket attacks by Palestinian militants on targets in southern Israel

item.title: Gaddafi's family escape to Algeria
item.description: Dictator's wife and three children cross the border unhindered in a motorcade, raising questions about NTC control over central Libya. A diplomatic standoff ensues as the NTC claims Algeria's president authorised the family's entry

item.title: EU to impose oil embargo on Syria
item.description: Officials say cutting 3bn annual lifeline and effectively halting all business between Syria and EU will be serious blow to regime

item.title: Iran frees 100 political prisoners
item.description: Tehran pardons prisoners in effort to ease political tension before parliamentary elections in March

item.title: Attorney general of Hama resigns in protest at crackdown
item.description: Adnan Muhammad al-Bakkour declares himself 'with the rebels' and claims security forces have killed hundreds in embattled city. He says the regime asked him to report that 'armed gangs' killed hundreds buried in mass graves

item.title: Rebels surround town where Gaddafi is believed to be hiding
item.description: Search for members of Gaddafi family focuses on town of Bani Walid, 100 miles south-east of Tripoli, as deposed leader vows in audio message to Syrian TV to keep fighting

item.title: UK attacks Gaddafi strongholds
item.description: British forces attack Gaddafi's last strongholds including Bani Walid as rebels prepare for an all-out assault on the town where they believe senior regime officials are hiding

item.title: EU bans import of Syrian oil
item.description: EU governments ban imports of Syrian oil and extend sanctions to intensify pressure on Assad, who has ignored calls for his resignation. Analysts say these first EU sanctions on Syrian industry may not curtail Assad's access to funds

item.title: Red Cross chief visits Damascus
item.description: The head of the International Committee of the Red Cross visits Damascus to seek access to arrested activists as at least 14 people are reportedly shot dead across Syria

item.title: Pro-Gaddafi convoy enters Niger
item.description: The head of Gaddafi's security brigades flees to Niger. A large pro-Gaddafi convoy is reportedly in Niger; loyalists deny Gaddafi is among the party. Gaddafi's besieged stronghold of Bani Walid faces humanitarian crisis

item.title: MI6 knew I was being tortured, rebel leader says
item.description: Abdul Hakim Belhaj, a Libyan rebel leader who was rendered to Tripoli with the assistance of MI6, says he told British intelligence officers he was being tortured but they did nothing to help him

item.title: Top officer denies police were ordered to fire on protesters
item.description: General Hussein Saeed Mohamed Mursi, a senior police witness in the trial of Hosni Mubarak, says he was not aware of any order to open fire on protesters who ousted the former Egyptian president

item.title: Jailed Bahrain activists stage hunger strike
item.description: More than 100 jailed Bahraini activists including doctors who treated injured protesters are on hunger strike, an international panel says. Hundreds of activists have been imprisoned and over 30 killed in Shia-led demonstrations for greater rights

item.title: Syrian violence escalates
item.description: Syria's violence escalates sharply, with up to 28 people reportedly killed across the country as France bluntly accuses Bashar al-Assad's regime of committing crimes against humanity

item.title: Gaddafi issues defiant message from hiding
item.description: Muammar Gaddafi issue a defiant message from hiding in which he vows 'never to leave the land of his ancestors' and denieds claims he had fled the country for neighbouring Niger

item.title: Soldiers 'executed' for refusing to target activists
item.description: Eight soldiers are executed in Damascus for refusing to fire on protesters, activists have claimed

item.title: Crowds storm Israel's Cairo embassy
item.description: Israel evacuates its Egyptian ambassador after crowds storm the embassy in Cairo, precipitating a diplomatic crisis. A senior Egyptian official says at least three people died and more than 1,000 were hurt during clashes with police and troops

item.title: Gaddafi's son Saadi 'has arrived in Niger'
item.description: Muammar Gaddafi's son Saadi has entered the territory of Libya's southern neighbour Niger, Niger's justice minister says

item.title: Russia refuses more Syria sanctions
item.description: Russia rebuffs western attempts to increase the pressure on the Syrian regime as new United Nations figures show at least 2,600 people have been killed since anti-government protests erupted in March

item.title: Gaddafi forces kill 17 at oil refinery
item.description: Forces loyal to Gaddafi kill 17 guards outside an oil refinery near Ras Lanouf in a surprise attack that demonstrated his toppled regime is not dead. Employees set fire to the facility and five saboteurs were killed

item.title: Erdogan in Cairo
item.description: Turkish PM Recep Tayyip Erdogan visits Cairo and insists Arab states must recognise Palestine. Meanwhile Egypt's ruling military council reactivates an emergency law that journalists fear may be used to muzzle the media

item.title: New leader calls for unity and moderation
item.description: Mustafa Abdul Jalil, chairman of Libya's transitional government, seeks to allay fears of factional splits, telling a crowd of 10,000 that 'moderate Islam' should be the basis of legislation and that women would continue to play key roles

item.title: Iranian lawyer Nasrin Sotoudeh has jail sentence reduced
item.description: Human rights lawyer who defended protesters has had her prison sentence cut from 11 years to six, her husband says

item.title: Cameron and Sarkozy meet new Libyan leaders
item.description: David Cameron and Nicolas Sarkozy fly into Libya and warn Syria and other Middle East regimes that 'the Arab spring could become an Arab summer'. The pair receive an enthusiastic welcome from Libya's interim rulers

item.title: Turkey blamed after defector is returned to Syria
item.description: Lieutenant Colonel Hussein al-Harmoush, the first senior military officer to defect during the Syrian uprising, is arrested by regime officials after allegedly being traded by Turkey for nine PKK prisoners

item.title: Rebels advance on Sirte
item.description: Libyan rebel fighters are involved in heavy fighting in a final battle to capture Muammar Gaddafi's hometown of Sirte, one of the last three significant strongholds still held by the old regime

item.title: Egyptians rally in Tahrir Square against return of emergency laws
item.description: Egyptians return to Tahrir Square to rally against the military junta's reactivation of Mubarak-era emergency laws, which Amnesty International describes as the biggest threat to human rights in Egypt since the Mubarak era

item.title: Syrian boy, 11, shot dead in protest
item.description: At least one child is shot dead and another arrested as Syrian pupils protests against the government on the first day of the school year. Activists say Ibrahim Mohammed al-Farouj was killed by a bullet to the head

item.title: Tensions over appointment of Libyan cabinet
item.description: Libya's new leaders fail to agree on expanding their interim cabinet, in an apparent sign of divisions over the appointment of Islamists. Fighting continues for control of Sirte and Bani Walid, strategic Gaddafi strongholds

item.title: Troops fire on protesters
item.description: Yemeni forces reportedly open fire with anti-aircraft guns and automatic weapons on tens of thousands of anti-government protesters gathered in Sana'a to demand the removal of President Saleh, killing at least 26 people and wounding dozens, witnesses say

item.title: Key military gain for free Libyan forces
item.description: Free Libyan forces take key parts of Sabha, a bastion of support for Gaddafi and other regime fugitives, the new rebel government says. Heavy fighting continues in Bani Walid, where Saif al-Islam al-Gaddafi is reportedly spotted

item.title: 22 killed and 350 hurt in bloodiest day
item.description: More than 22 protesters are killed and at least 350 wounded in the stand-off between anti-government groups and loyalist security forces

item.title: Gaddafi taunts Nato in new radio address
item.description: The bombs of Nato planes will not last. The political system in Libya is a system based on the power of the people ... and it is impossible that this system be removed', deposed leader tells Syrian TV

item.title: Protest camp shelled as crackdown continues
item.description: Rockets hit a protest camp in Sana'a, killing at least six people on a third day of violence in the government's deadliest crackdown yet on pro-democracy demonstrations. Later an uneasy ceasefire is negotiated

item.title: Plan to avoid showdown over Palestinian statehood
item.description: Efforts to forestall a security council showdown over a Palestinian statehood declaration continue. The 'Quartet' want Mahmoud Abbas to submit the request but for a vote (which the US pledges to veto) to be delayed pending new talks

item.title: Five killed as ceasefire breaks
item.description: Five protesters are killed when Sana'a's ceasefire is broken by gunfire and shelling against a protest camp. 100,000 attend the funeral of 83 people killed in three days. Obama calls for a peaceful transition of power from Saleh

item.title: Obama urges UN security council sanctions on Assad
item.description: Obama condemns torture, detention and murder by the Syrian government and urges the UN security council to sanction Assad's regime. A headteacher becomes one of the latest victims of the crackdown, activists claim, as security forces target schools

item.title: Gaddafi's prime minister arrested in Tunisia
item.description: Al-Baghdadi Ali al-Mahmoudi is most senior member of ousted Libyan regime captured since rebel takeover

item.title: Cameron urges UN action against oppressive regimes
item.description: Cameron says the Arab Spring shows the UN must be readier to act against oppressive regimes. Ahmadinejad's UN speech attacks Zionism and propounds 9/11 conspiracy theories. Gaddafi's PM is arrested in Tunisia; Libyan rebels discover chemical weapons

item.title: First woman to die in custody
item.description: Zainab al-Hosni, 18, is believed to be the first female to die in custody during the uprising. Amnesty International says relatives found her decapitated and mutilated corpse while searching a morgue in Homs for her activist brother's body

item.title: Saleh's shock return prompts turmoil
item.description: President Saleh returns unexpectedly after three months recovering in Saudi Arabia from an assassination attempt and calls for a truce after five days of brutal violence in Sana'a in which more than 100 protesters have been shot dead

item.title: 40 killed in fierce fighting
item.description: At least 40 people are killed amid fierce fighting on three fronts in Sana'a between troops loyal to President Saleh and a rebel army division, tribal fighters and pro-democracy demonstrators

item.title: Palestinian Spring starts here, Abbas says
item.description: The Palestinian leadership is to press for a swift vote on its demand for full statehood at the UN security council as President Mahmoud Abbas returns to Ramallah to tell cheering crowds that the 'Palestinian Spring' has begun

item.title: Sirte 'close to falling'
item.description: Government forces approach central Sirte; Nato orders a halt to fighting to enable its planes to destroy pro-Gaddafi artillery. A mass grave containing 1,270 bodies is discovered in Tripoli. Regime supporters launch an attack across the Algerian border

item.title: Libyan government seeks Algerian answers over cross-border attack
item.description: Eight NTC fighters killed in attack by pro-Gaddafi forces near Ghadames, while siege of Sirte continues

item.title: Saleh calls election as violence continues
item.description: President Saleh calls for early elections in his first speech since returning to Yemen after an assassination attempt. He has made repeated proposals to end violence; protesters want his immediate departure. 100 died in the last six days

item.title: Saudi women to get right to vote
item.description: King Abdullah announces 'cautious reform' in the rigidly conservative Islamic kingdom, whereby women will get the right to vote and stand for election from 2015 and will be allowed to take part in the next shura legislative council

item.title: At least six dead in government crackdown
item.description: Six protesters are reported killed, including four in Hama, and the government's news agency claims a gang killed a warrant officer. Online activists claim to have hacked into government websites. Army defectors declare 'the beginning of armed rebellion'

item.title: Libya 'will co-operate on Lockerbie investigation'
item.description: A day after a British trade delegation visits Tripoli, the Foreign Office says Libyan authorities have promised to co-operate with the Scottish investigation into the Lockerbie bombing, contradicting reports that Libya's justice minister had pronounced the case 'closed'

item.title: Elections to begin on 28 November
item.description: Military regime announces first parliamentary elections since Mubarak was ousted but opposition groups fear rules will allow remnants of the old regime to remain in power

item.title: Saudi women to stand trial for driving
item.description: Women's rights activist Najla Hariri and others due to face court accused of flouting kingdom's driving ban

item.title: Palestinian statehood bid kicked into committee by UN security council
item.description: Move comes as efforts to launch fresh peace talks are threatened by row over new Jewish settlement in East Jerusalem

item.title: Tens of thousands protest over Saleh's return
item.description: Yemenis demand removal of after Ali Abdullah Saleh in Sana'a, while opposition tribesmen say they shot down a warplane

item.title: Doctors jailed for treating injured protesters
item.description: Twenty medics who treated activists wounded during uprising in Gulf kingdom jailed by military court for between five and 15 years in sentences that were immediately denounced by medical bodies and human rights groups around the world

item.title: Truce broken by heavy shelling in Sana'a
item.description: Residents flee as fighting resumes in capital, ending three-day ceasefire called by President Saleh on his unexpected return

item.title: Saudi woman driver saved from lashing by King Abdullah
item.description: Shaima Jastaina had been sentenced to be lashed 10 times after being found guilty of driving a car without permission

item.title: Clinton condemns attack on ambassador and fighting erupts around Rastan
item.description: Hillary Clinton speaks out after US ambassador Robert Ford's convoy was attacked as he travelled to meet a leading opponent of Assad regime. Meanwhile, competing claims emerge about violence sparked by army defections in central town of Rastan

item.title: Protestors demand quicker move to democracy
item.description: Thousands of Egyptians rally under the slogan Reclaiming the Revolution in cities across the country, as frustration grows with slow pace of reform and reintroduction of Mubarak-era emergency laws under military regime

item.title: Mystery surrounds suicide of Iranian bloggers
item.description: Opposition supporters believe young couple were pressured to testify against Kouhyar Goudarzi, the human rights activist missing since July

item.title: Rebels unite to oust Assad and push for democracy
item.description: Opposition groups form national council to 'achieve the wishes and hopes of our people in overthrowing the current regime'

item.title: Sirte residents queue to leave city during two-day ceasefire
item.description: Temporary truce precedes expected all-out attack on remaining pro-Gaddafi loyalists as conditions deteriorate for remaining residents

item.title: Israel must restart talks with its neighbours, says US
item.description: Defence secretary Leon Panetta says Israel needs to focus on restarting negotiations with the Palestinians and restoring relations with Egypt and Turkey

item.title: Turkey imposes sanctions on Syria in protest over deaths
item.description: Turkish prime minster, Recep Erdogan, turns on former ally and vows not to remain a bystander in the face of crackdown

item.title: In pictures: The battle for Sirte
item.description: Heavy fighting continues as anti-Gaddafi fighters backed by Nato aircraft make slow progress in efforts to capture dictator's home town

item.title: Retrial for medics jailed for treating protesters
item.description: Prosecutor orders civilian retrials for 20 medical personnel after global condemnation of sentences

item.title: Russia and China veto UN resolution against Syrian regime
item.description: Anger from Europe and US as two security council powers argue implied threat of sanctions will not bring peace

item.title: Unrest reported in eastern Saudi Arabia - video
item.description: Amateur footage purports to show anti-government protests and clashes in the kingdom's oil-rich eastern province, in which Riyadh acknowledged 14 people had been injured

item.title: Generals accused of buying time to stay in power
item.description: Supreme Council of the Armed Forces unveils plans that could see them retain power until 2013, increasing unease that promised transition to civilian rule is being unneccesarily delayed

item.title: Anti-Gaddafi troops meet fierce resistance in Sirte
item.description: Hundreds of revolutionary fighters pour into coastal city as pro-Gaddafi defenders counter with intense sniper fire

item.title: Assad should reform or quit, says Dmitry Medvedev
item.description: Despite previous veto of UN resolution threatening sanctions against Syrian regime, Russian president breaks ranks with Bashar al-Assad for the first time since protests started

item.title: Police use teargas at protest over teenager's death
item.description: Ahmed Jaber, 17, was hit by birdshot when riot police and demonstrators clashed, opposition says

item.title: Tawakkul Karman wins Nobel peace prize
item.description: Yemeni journalist, pro-democracy activist and leading figure in the protests against President Saleh is one of three women jointly awarded the 2011 peace prize by the Nobel committee

item.title: Activist lashed 74 times for 'insult' to Ahmadinejad
item.description: Political science student, Peyman Aref, is whipped hours before release from one-year jail sentence in 'unprecedented' punishment imposed after being arrested in the aftermath of Iran's disputed 2009 presidential elections

item.title: Cairo clashes leave at least 24 dead
item.description: Military police blamed for using excessive force as protest march by Christians over church attack erupts into worst violence since fall of Mubarak

item.title: Opposition leader released from house arrest to see his family
item.description: Security officials allow Mehdi Karroubi, held incommunicado since February when he called on the reformist 'Green movement' to rally in support of Arab uprisings, to celebrate his 74th birthday with relatives

item.title: Coptic Christians face an uncertain future
item.description: William Dalrymple on why the Egyptian army's violent suppression of a Christian protest in Cairo reflects the growing threat to the country's large Coptic minority

item.title: China urges regime to deliver on promised reforms
item.description: Beijing move seen as sign of waning patience over ongoing violence and follows Russia's call for Assad to reform or quit

item.title: Cairo witnesses blame security forces for bloodshed at Coptic march
item.description: Four protestors give testimonies that contradict official accounts of the violence that left 26 people dead and 500 injured after a march by Coptic Christians

item.title: Gilad Shalit prisoner swap deal reached
item.description: Israeli and Hamas officials reach deal that would secure imminent release of the Israeli soldier held captive in the Gaza Strip for five year

item.title: Israel apologises to Egypt over police officer deaths
item.description: Defence minister's statement follows investigation into clash between Israeli forces and suspected Palestinian militants in August that killed six Egyptian personnel

item.title: US citizen charged with spying on protesters for Assad regime
item.description: Syrian-born man arrested in Virginia for passing sensitive information on anti-Assad protesters in US to Damascus

item.title: Syria heading for civil war, top UN official warns
item.description: Ten people have died in the latest clashes as protesters urge more people to defect from the Syrian security forces

item.title: Government loyalists kill 12 at protest rally in Sana'a
item.description: Security forces and plain-clothed government supporters launch coordinated attack on mass rally in Yemeni capital calling for President Saleh's resignation. Twelve are killed and dozens wounded, raising fears that country could slide into civil war

item.title: Six killed as anti-Saleh protestors targeted again
item.description: Six people, including a 20-year-old woman, shot dead as pro-government snipers attack demonstrators in the Yemeni capital for the second day running

item.title: Bulldozers begin demolition of Gaddafi's Tripoli compound
item.description: Knocking down Gaddafi's Tripoli stronghold is seen by revolutionaries as erasing 'symbol of repression'

item.title: Capital rocked by night of fierce fighting
item.description: Change Square sees some of the worst violence in months as government loyalists battle rebel tribesmen and defected soldiers. Protesters are said to be writing their names across their chests for identification in case they die while marching

item.title: Gaddafi stronghold Bani Walid falls
item.description: NTC troops raise flags of Libya's new government after six-week siege, leaving only parts of Sirte defended by loyalists

item.title: Jordan's king sacks prime minister
item.description: Marouf al-Bakhit asked to resign following accusations of incompetence and failing to push through reforms to defuse popular criticism

item.title: More unarmed protesters mown down by pro-government gunmen
item.description: Crackdown continues unabated as Saleh loyalists attack another mass demonstration, killing seven and wounding more than 50

item.title: Jailed blogger on hunger strike declares himself ready to die
item.description: Maikel Nabil Sanad declares he would prefer suicide to being tried by military junta for criticising the army in his blog, as his fast enters its 57th day

item.title: Day of euphoria as Gilad Shalit released
item.description: Israeli relief tinged with anxiety over soldier's physical and mental state as Palestinians welcome back hundreds of prisoners following swap deal agreed to end Shalit's five-year captivity

item.title: Film director loses appeal against six-year prison sentence
item.description: Tehran appeal court upholds sentence against Jafar Panahi that includes a 20-year ban on film-making, travelling abroad or talking to the press

item.title: Elections will map out a path for the Arab spring
item.description: Ian Black on how the first country to overthrow its dictator is again the focus of international attention as Tunisia prepares for its first-ever free elections and the first free elections in the region since the Arab spring

item.title: Libya leads world in recognising Syrian opposition
item.description: Assad faces further pressure as Libya's interim government becomes the first in the world to back Syrian National Council as a "legitimate authority" to rule the country

item.title: Muammar Gaddafi killed as his home town finally falls
item.description: Cornered by government forces and pinned down by NATO airstrikes, Gaddafi is found alive, reportedly trying to flee Sirte. Graphic footage of the ensuing chaos suggests he quickly met a brutal end at his captors' hands

item.title: Doctor jailed for treating injured protesters speaks - audio
item.description: The Bahraini medic Rula al-Saffar speaks about her arrest and mistreatment in jail following the uprising in March. She is one of 20 medics sentenced to between five and 20 years in prison

item.title: Activists say 14 killed as Gaddaffi death inspires protests
item.description: Central city of Hama, a hotbed of anti-regime resistance, sees protestors demanding international military intervention and vowing that Assad's 'turn' is next, following demise of Libyan dictator

item.title: Hundreds queue to see Gaddafi's body on display in Misrata
item.description: Corpse becomes macabre spectacle as Libyans queue outside refrigerated meat store to confirm that the dictator is really dead. The body of his son, Mutassim, also captured alive but killed in uncertain circumstances, is also displayed

item.title: Death of heir to Saudi throne raises succession questions
item.description: The death of Crown Prince Sultan bin Abdul-Aziz al Saud means the likely successor to King Abdullah is ultraconservative Prince Nayef, who was directly involved in sending soldiers into Bahrain to help crush pro-reform demonstrations in March

item.title: Tunisian elections: polling day as it happened
item.description: Read how the events of an historic day unfolded as Tunisians went to the polls nine months after they took to the streets

item.title: Bahraini medics retrial under way in civilian court
item.description: Second trial for 20 hospital staff follows UN criticism of convictions for protest-related charges

item.title: Benghazi's moment of joy as Libya's tyranny officially ends
item.description: National Transitional Council announces liberation to elated crowds in city where uprising began

item.title: Saudi film-makers enter second week of detention
item.description: Feras Boqna, Hussam al-Drewesh and Khaled al-Rasheed detained after posting 10-minute film on Saudis living in poverty to YouTube

item.title: Video: Tunisia's voters go to the polls
item.description: People queue to vote as candidates from 110 political parties and scores of independents contest the Arab spring's first election

item.title: Israeli officer loses command, a month after death of protester
item.description: Action against officer in charge of army unit that killed Palestinian in Qusra was taken due to 'a number of incidents'

item.title: US pulls ambassador out of Syria over security concerns
item.description: Robert Ford who angered Syrian regime over his support for anti-regime protesters leaves Damascus after an intimidation campaign and what US officials call 'credible' threats against his life

item.title: Islamist party wins Tunisian elections
item.description: Partial results from home and abroad suggest An-Nahda has won 24 out of 57 assembly seats so far, or just over 42% of total

item.title: Gaddafi buried in secret desert location
item.description: Dictator's burial alongside his son Mutassim brings to close controversy over public display of his body for nearly four days

item.title: Wounded Syrian protesters being tortured in hospital, claims Amnesty
item.description: Syrian regime uses hospitals as 'instruments of repression', says report, adding that some medics are involved in abuses

item.title: Yemeni women set veils ablaze in protest at regime violence
item.description: Women's protest in Sana'a comes after overnight clashes in the capital and in Taiz leave as many as 25 people dead

item.title: Interactive: full election results
item.description: Track how the seats in Tunisia's Constituent Assembly were divided up

item.title: Lenient sentences condemned in police brutality case
item.description: Two policemen who dragged Khaled Said, 28, from an Alexandria internet cafe and beat him to death in June 2010 are jailed for seven years. A memorial Facebook page helped mobilise the anti-Mubarak protests in January

item.title: Gaddafi killer faces prosecution, says Libyan interim government
item.description: NTC backs down from insistence Gaddafi died in crossfire and pledges justice for anyone proven to have fired lethal shot

item.title: Sidi Bouzid under curfew as violence erupts following election
item.description: Town that initiated revolution reacts angrily to decision to annul victories for Popular Petition party sponsored by London-based political exile

item.title: Anger grows after latest case of death by torture
item.description: Critics say 24-year-old Essam Ali Atta's death at the hands of prison guards shows military junta is failing to dismantle Mubarak's brutal security apparatus

item.title: Saif al-Islam Gaddafi contacts International Criminal Court
item.description: The court establishes an indirect link with Gaddafi's fugitive son, who is believed to be attempting to reach Niger or Mali from southern Libya

item.title: Syrian forces kill 40 as Arab League denounces attacks
item.description: Arab ministers send their strongest message yet calling for an end to civilian killings after latest shootings at post-Friday prayers protests

item.title: Iranian actress released from jail
item.description: Marzieh Vafamehr, who appeared with a shaved head and without a hijab in a film critical of Iran's repressive policies, has harsh sentence of one year in prison and 90 lashes overturned on appeal

item.title: Gaza militants agree truce after nine killed in Israeli raids
item.description: Islamic Jihad says it will stop firing rockets if retaliatory air strikes cease after militants and Israeli civilian killed in cross-border flare-up

item.title: Nato all but rules out Syria no-fly zone
item.description: Syrian president warns that intervention could lead to 'another Afghanistan' as Nato officials say Libya-like action lacks support

item.title: US pulls Unesco funding after Palestine granted membership
item.description: Palestinian Authority's bid to join the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation given overwhelming backing in defiance of American, Israeli and European pressure and despite US threat of withholding 50m in funds

item.title: Nato ends military operations in Libya
item.description: Secretary general rules out intervention in Syria as he hails aerial campaign which destroyed much of Gaddafi's military infrastructure as a 'successful chapter' in alliance's history

item.title: Egyptian revolutionary Alaa Abd El Fattah arrested by junta
item.description: Mubarak opponent and blogger refuses to recognise authority of prosecutors after charge of inciting violence against military, provoking the biggest crisis yet in relations between pro-change activists and the increasingly repressive army junta

item.title: Israel rushes settlement growth after Unesco accepts Palestinians
item.description: Punitive measure agreed by Israeli cabinet, as West Bank and Gaza internet services come under attacK by unknown hackers in multiple locations

item.title: Syria nuclear weapons site revealed by UN investigators
item.description: IAEA identifies uranium enrichment plant design at Hasakah and finds correspondence with Pakistan atomic expert, sources claim

item.title: Junta pledges to free hundreds after prison letter published
item.description: Generals announce pardon for 334 inmates, following reaction to letter secretly written by activist Alaa Abd El Fattah from his cell

item.title: Egyptians call for day of action to revive revolution
item.description: Activists claim their revolution is "under attack" and appeal for solidarity from the worldwide Occupy movement. Meanwhile, a military court refuses the appeal of Alaa Abd El Fattah, whose incarceration has become a focal point of protests

item.title: Syrian tanks shell Homs hours after Arab League peace deal
item.description: Activists claim at least seven people killed in besieged city less than a day after Damascus appeared to sign up to an Arab League plan to withdraw armoured vehicles

item.title: Libyans try to get back property seized by Gaddafi
item.description: Spray paint messages highlight minefield for new rulers, as original owners demand restitution for buildings worth billions

item.title: Crackdown continues prompting urgent Arab League talks
item.description: Arab League arranges emergency meeting to discuss Assad's failure to stick to peace plan after death of 13 on Islamic holy day

item.title: Syrian regime has killed more than 3,500, says UN
item.description: Estimate of death toll emerges as military continues campaign against Homs protesters despite Arab League peace deal

item.title: Alaa Abd El Fattah's mother goes on hunger strike
item.description: Laila Soueif, who is in her late 50s, is protesting at the continued imprisonment by Egypt's military rulers of her son, one of the country's most vocal activists and bloggers

item.title: UN vote on Palestinian state postponed amid lack of support
item.description: Security Council puts off statehood decision while the Palestinian leadership decides whether to force the issue, after mustering only eight of nine votes needed to win approval

item.title: Niger grants asylum to Saadi Gaddafi
item.description: Son of Muammar Gaddafi is being treated as refugee in Niger, confirms President Mahamadou Issoufou who also denies knowledge of Saif al-Islam's whereabouts

item.title: Yemen's Hirak rebels emerge from the shadows
item.description: Leader of southern secessionist movement calls for beleaguered regime in Sana'a to accept self-determination demands or face prospect of the country once more splitting in two

item.title: Syria suspended from Arab League
item.description: Member states agree to exclude Syria and impose sanctions over its failure to end government crackdown on protests

item.title: Syria reacts furiously to Arab League suspension
item.description: Saudi, Qatari, French, and Turkish embassies stormed by pro-Assad supporters as regime demands emergency Arab League meeting and violence escalates in Hama

item.title: Egyptian protesters killed in clashes with security forces
item.description: Egypt sees violence escalate as protests against ruling military junta spread beyond Cairo and Alexandria

item.title: Assad should quit, says King of Jordan
item.description: Pressure mounts on increasingly isolated Syrian president as King Abdullah follows Arab League action by saying Bashar al-Assad would resign if he 'considers the interest of his country'

item.title: Fledgling Libyan army steps in to subdue inter-militia violence
item.description: Hundreds of uniformed men described as members of a new Libyan army are deployed for the first time, to settle a bloody feud between rival militias, officials say

item.title: Syria urged to stop violent repression
item.description: Human rights groups say that up to 140 people have been killed since Arab League voted to suspend Syrian membership

item.title: Palestinians protest Israeli bus policy
item.description: Israeli authorities accused of operating a policy of racial segregation as six Palestinian activists arrested while attempting to enter Jerusalem on a bus carrying settlers through the occupied West Bank

item.title: Court rules former Mubarak party members can contest election
item.description: Decision overturns earlier ruling that would have seen members of the dismantled National Democratic party barred from running as candidates in forthcoming election

item.title: Syrian army defectors attack intelligence base near Damascus
item.description: Members of the Free Syrian Army hit a string of military bases near Damascus, including an intelligence complex, in the first such reported assault on a major security facility in the eight-month uprising

item.title: Kuwait security crackdown after crowd storms parliament
item.description: Emir denounces protest as threat to country's stability and calls for 'stricter measures to confront chaotic behaviour' after anti-corruption protestors surge past police barricades

item.title: UN security council must act, say France and Turkey
item.description: Foreign ministers keep up pressure on Assad to end violence, as Damascus agrees in principle to Arab League monitors in Syria

item.title: Egyptians return to Tahrir Square to protest against junta
item.description: Thousands gather for one of the largest demonstrations since Hosni Mubarak was ousted and new rulers took over

item.title: Violent clashes in Cairo leave two dead and hundreds injured
item.description: Egyptian security forces open fire on thousands of anti-junta protesters in Tahrir Square, leaving two dead, more than 600 injured and the ability of the authorities to secure the forthcoming parliamentary elections in doubt

item.title: Saif al-Islam Gaddafi captured alive in Libya
item.description: Celebrations erupt as Muammar Gaddafi's fugitive son detained without firing a shot while attempting to flee to Niger

item.title: In pictures: Tahrir Square a battleground once again
item.description: Violence in Cairo continues for a second day as security forces use teargas, rubber bullets and batons to evict several thousand protesters from Tahrir Square, leaving at least three dead. The protestors later retake the crucial landmark.

item.title: Gaddafi's intelligence chief captured in southern desert
item.description: Abdullah al-Senussi's detention near to where Saif al-Islam Gaddafi was apprehended means all leading figures from the Gaddafi regime have now either been killed, captured or driven into exile

item.title: Rebels attack Ba'ath party offices in Damascus
item.description: All-out civil war more likely after Free Syrian Army claims responsibility for grenade strike on ruling party's building

item.title: Egypt's cabinet offers resignation after third day of protest
item.description: Interim government bows to growing pressure as violence leaves 33 people dead and more than 2,000 injured in ongoing clashes

item.title: ICC says Saif al-Islam Gaddafi could face Libya trial
item.description: The international criminal court's chief prosecutor says son of Muammar Gaddafi could be tried in Libya rather than The Hague, meaning he faces the death penalty if convicted
